qTextArr:
['Oh, Mr. Fortescue,', 'I had
just written to say how I envied her! I was thinking of the big gardens
and the dear old ladies in mittens, who read nothing but the', 'and snuff the candles. Have they _all_ disappeared? I told
her she would find the nice things of London without the horrid streets
that depress one so.']
qText:
Oh, Mr. Fortescue, I had
just written to say how I envied her! I was thinking of the big gardens
and the dear old ladies in mittens, who read nothing but the and snuff the candles. Have they _all_ disappeared? I told
her she would find the nice things of London without the horrid streets
that depress one so.

qTextArr:
['Trafalgar, of course! How stupid of me! Another cup of tea, with a
thin slice of lemon in it, and then, dear Mr. Fortescue, please explain
my absurd little puzzle. One can t help believing gentlemen with Roman
noses, even if one meets them in omnibuses.']
qText:
Trafalgar, of course! How stupid of me! Another cup of tea, with a
thin slice of lemon in it, and then, dear Mr. Fortescue, please explain
my absurd little puzzle. One can t help believing gentlemen with Roman
noses, even if one meets them in omnibuses.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
addressee: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue']

qTextArr:
['D you know, Mr. Denham, you remind me so much of dear Mr.
Ruskin.... Is it his tie, Katharine, or his hair, or the way he sits in
his chair? Do tell me, Mr. Denham, are you an admirer of Ruskin? Some
one, the other day, said to me,  Oh, no, we don t read Ruskin, Mrs.
Hilbery.  What _do_ you read, I wonder? for you can t spend all your
time going up in aeroplanes and burrowing into the bowels of the
earth.']
qText:
D you know, Mr. Denham, you remind me so much of dear Mr.
Ruskin.... Is it his tie, Katharine, or his hair, or the way he sits in
his chair? Do tell me, Mr. Denham, are you an admirer of Ruskin? Some
one, the other day, said to me,  Oh, no, we don t read Ruskin, Mrs.
Hilbery.  What _do_ you read, I wonder? for you can t spend all your
time going up in aeroplanes and burrowing into the bowels of the
earth.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
addressee: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue']

qTextArr:
['I m sure Mr. Denham would like to see our things, Katharine. I m sure
he s not like that dreadful young man, Mr. Ponting, who told me that he
considered it our duty to live exclusively in the present. After all,
what IS the present? Half of it s the past, and the better half, too, I
should say,']
qText:
I m sure Mr. Denham would like to see our things, Katharine. I m sure
he s not like that dreadful young man, Mr. Ponting, who told me that he
considered it our duty to live exclusively in the present. After all,
what IS the present? Half of it s the past, and the better half, too, I
should say,
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
addressee: ['Mr. Hilbery', 'A Thin, Elderly Gentleman', 'Ralph Denham', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mr. Fortescue']

qText: This is his writing-table. He used this pen,

qTextArr:
['I think my grandfather must have been at least twice as large as any
one is nowadays. This,', 'is the original manuscript of the  Ode to Winter.  The early
poems are far less corrected than the later. Would you like to look at
it?']
qText:
I think my grandfather must have been at least twice as large as any
one is nowadays. This, is the original manuscript of the  Ode to Winter.  The early
poems are far less corrected than the later. Would you like to look at
it?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['This is a copy of the first edition of the poems,', 'which contains several poems that have not been\nreprinted, as well as corrections.']
qText:
This is a copy of the first edition of the poems, which contains several poems that have not been
reprinted, as well as corrections.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['That lady in blue is my great-grandmother, by Millington. Here is my
uncle s walking-stick he was Sir Richard Warburton, you know, and rode
with Havelock to the Relief of Lucknow. And then, let me see oh, that s
the original Alardyce, 1697, the founder of the family fortunes, with
his wife. Some one gave us this bowl the other day because it has their
crest and initials. We think it must have been given them to celebrate
their silver wedding-day.']
qText:
That lady in blue is my great-grandmother, by Millington. Here is my
uncle s walking-stick he was Sir Richard Warburton, you know, and rode
with Havelock to the Relief of Lucknow. And then, let me see oh, that s
the original Alardyce, 1697, the founder of the family fortunes, with
his wife. Some one gave us this bowl the other day because it has their
crest and initials. We think it must have been given them to celebrate
their silver wedding-day.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
refExp: She paused for a minute and then went on

qTextArr: ['You must be very proud of your family, Miss Hilbery.']
qText: You must be very proud of your family, Miss Hilbery.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Yes, I am,', 'Do you think there s\nanything wrong in that?']
qText:
Yes, I am, Do you think there s
anything wrong in that?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Wrong? How should it be wrong? It must be a bore, though, showing your\nthings to visitors,']
qText:
Wrong? How should it be wrong? It must be a bore, though, showing your
things to visitors,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Not if the visitors like them.']
qText: Not if the visitors like them.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Isn t it difficult to live up to your ancestors?']
qText: Isn t it difficult to live up to your ancestors?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['I dare say I shouldn t try to write poetry,']
qText: I dare say I shouldn t try to write poetry,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['No. And that s what I should hate. I couldn t bear my grandfather to
cut me out. And, after all,', 'it s not your grandfather only.
You re cut out all the way round. I suppose you come of one of the most
distinguished families in England. There are the Warburtons and the
Mannings and you re related to the Otways, aren t you? I read it all in
some magazine,']
qText:
No. And that s what I should hate. I couldn t bear my grandfather to
cut me out. And, after all, it s not your grandfather only.
You re cut out all the way round. I suppose you come of one of the most
distinguished families in England. There are the Warburtons and the
Mannings and you re related to the Otways, aren t you? I read it all in
some magazine,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['The Otways are my cousins,']
qText: The Otways are my cousins,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Well,']
qText: Well,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Well,', 'I don t see that you ve proved anything.']
qText: Well, I don t see that you ve proved anything.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Well,']
qText: Well,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['But aren t you proud of your family?']
qText: But aren t you proud of your family?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['No,', 'We ve never done anything to be proud of unless you\ncount paying one s bills a matter for pride.']
qText:
No, We ve never done anything to be proud of unless you
count paying one s bills a matter for pride.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['That sounds rather dull,']
qText: That sounds rather dull,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['You would think us horribly dull,']
qText: You would think us horribly dull,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Yes, I might find you dull, but I don t think I should find you\nridiculous,']
qText:
Yes, I might find you dull, but I don t think I should find you
ridiculous,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['No because we re not in the least ridiculous. We re a respectable\nmiddle-class family, living at Highgate.']
qText:
No because we re not in the least ridiculous. We re a respectable
middle-class family, living at Highgate.
speaker: Ralph Denham
menEnts: [[['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery']]]

qTextArr: ['We don t live at Highgate, but we re middle class too, I suppose.']
qText: We don t live at Highgate, but we re middle class too, I suppose.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['That belonged to Clive, so we say,']
qText: That belonged to Clive, so we say,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Is it a lie?']
qText: Is it a lie?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['It s a family tradition. I don t know that we can prove it.']
qText: It s a family tradition. I don t know that we can prove it.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['You see, we don t have traditions in our family,']
qText: You see, we don t have traditions in our family,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['You sound very dull,']
qText: You sound very dull,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Merely middle class,']
qText: Merely middle class,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['You pay your bills, and you speak the truth. I don t see why you\nshould despise us.']
qText:
You pay your bills, and you speak the truth. I don t see why you
should despise us.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I shouldn t like to be you; that s all I said,']
qText: I shouldn t like to be you; that s all I said,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['No, but one never would like to be any one else.']
qText: No, but one never would like to be any one else.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I should. I should like to be lots of other people.']
qText: I should. I should like to be lots of other people.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Then why not us?']
qText: Then why not us?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['You ll never know anything at first hand,', 'It s all been done for you. You ll never know the pleasure of buying\nthings after saving up for them, or reading books for the first time,\nor making discoveries.']
qText:
You ll never know anything at first hand, It s all been done for you. You ll never know the pleasure of buying
things after saving up for them, or reading books for the first time,
or making discoveries.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Go on,']
qText: Go on,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Of course, I don t know how you spend your time,', 'but I suppose you have to show people round. You are\nwriting a life of your grandfather, aren t you? And this kind of\nthing', 'must take up a lot of time.']
qText:
Of course, I don t know how you spend your time, but I suppose you have to show people round. You are
writing a life of your grandfather, aren t you? And this kind of
thing must take up a lot of time.
speaker: Ralph Denham
menEnts: [[['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Richard Alardyce'], ['Katharine Hilbery']], []]

qTextArr: ['You ve got it very nearly right,', 'but I only help my\nmother. I don t write myself.']
qText:
You ve got it very nearly right, but I only help my
mother. I don t write myself.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Do you do anything yourself?']
qText: Do you do anything yourself?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['What do you mean?', 'I don t leave the house at ten and come\nback at six.']
qText:
What do you mean? I don t leave the house at ten and come
back at six.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I don t mean that.']
qText: I don t mean that.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr:
['Nobody ever does do anything worth doing nowadays,', 'You
see', 'we don t even
print as well as they did, and as for poets or painters or
novelists there are none; so, at any rate, I m not singular.']
qText:
Nobody ever does do anything worth doing nowadays, You
see we don t even
print as well as they did, and as for poets or painters or
novelists there are none; so, at any rate, I m not singular.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['No, we haven t any great men,', 'I m very glad that we\nhaven t. I hate great men. The worship of greatness in the nineteenth\ncentury seems to me to explain the worthlessness of that generation.']
qText:
No, we haven t any great men, I m very glad that we
haven t. I hate great men. The worship of greatness in the nineteenth
century seems to me to explain the worthlessness of that generation.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Well,', 'how do you like our things, Mr. Denham?']
qText: Well, how do you like our things, Mr. Denham?
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['There are some books that _live_,', 'They are young with us,
and they grow old with us. Are you fond of poetry, Mr. Denham? But what
an absurd question to ask! The truth is, dear Mr. Fortescue has almost
tired me out. He is so eloquent and so witty, so searching and so
profound that, after half an hour or so, I feel inclined to turn out
all the lights. But perhaps he d be more wonderful than ever in the
dark. What d you think, Katharine? Shall we give a little party in
complete darkness? There d have to be bright rooms for the bores....']
qText:
There are some books that _live_, They are young with us,
and they grow old with us. Are you fond of poetry, Mr. Denham? But what
an absurd question to ask! The truth is, dear Mr. Fortescue has almost
tired me out. He is so eloquent and so witty, so searching and so
profound that, after half an hour or so, I feel inclined to turn out
all the lights. But perhaps he d be more wonderful than ever in the
dark. What d you think, Katharine? Shall we give a little party in
complete darkness? There d have to be bright rooms for the bores....
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
menEnts: [[], [['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Mr. Fortescue'], ['Mr. Fortescue'], ['Mr. Fortescue'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

qTextArr:
['But we ve any number of things to show you!', 'Books, pictures, china, manuscripts, and the
very chair that Mary Queen of Scots sat in when she heard of Darnley s
murder. I must lie down for a little, and Katharine must change her
dress (though she s wearing a very pretty one), but if you don t mind
being left alone, supper will be at eight. I dare say you ll write a
poem of your own while you re waiting. Ah, how I love the firelight!
Doesn t our room look charming?']
qText:
But we ve any number of things to show you! Books, pictures, china, manuscripts, and the
very chair that Mary Queen of Scots sat in when she heard of Darnley s
murder. I must lie down for a little, and Katharine must change her
dress (though she s wearing a very pretty one), but if you don t mind
being left alone, supper will be at eight. I dare say you ll write a
poem of your own while you re waiting. Ah, how I love the firelight!
Doesn t our room look charming?
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
menEnts: [[['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery'], ['Ralph Denham']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham']]]

qTextArr:
['Dear things!', 'Dear chairs and tables! How like old
friends they are faithful, silent friends. Which reminds me, Katharine,
little Mr. Anning is coming to-night, and Tite Street, and Cadogan
Square.... Do remember to get that drawing of your great-uncle glazed.
Aunt Millicent remarked it last time she was here, and I know how it
would hurt me to see _my_ father in a broken glass.']
qText:
Dear things! Dear chairs and tables! How like old
friends they are faithful, silent friends. Which reminds me, Katharine,
little Mr. Anning is coming to-night, and Tite Street, and Cadogan
Square.... Do remember to get that drawing of your great-uncle glazed.
Aunt Millicent remarked it last time she was here, and I know how it
would hurt me to see _my_ father in a broken glass.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['She ll do.... Yes, Katharine Hilbery ll do.... I ll take Katharine\nHilbery.']
qText:
She ll do.... Yes, Katharine Hilbery ll do.... I ll take Katharine
Hilbery.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Mother says, aren t you coming down, Ralph? Uncle Joseph']
qText: Mother says, aren t you coming down, Ralph? Uncle Joseph
speaker: A Small Girl
refExp: a small girl popped her head in to say

qTextArr: ['They re to bring my dinner up here,']
qText: They re to bring my dinner up here,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Ralph!']
qText: Ralph!
speaker: A Voice From Within

qTextArr: ['Ralph?']
qText: Ralph?
speaker: Joan

qTextArr: ['Joan?']
qText: Joan?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['I was coming up, but I saw your notice.']
qText: I was coming up, but I saw your notice.
speaker: Joan

qTextArr: ['Well, come along in, then.']
qText: Well, come along in, then.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['It s about Charles and Uncle John s offer.... Mother s been talking to\nme. She says she can t afford to pay for him after this term. She says\nshe ll have to ask for an overdraft as it is.']
qText:
It s about Charles and Uncle John s offer.... Mother s been talking to
me. She says she can t afford to pay for him after this term. She says
she ll have to ask for an overdraft as it is.
speaker: Joan
menEnts: [[['Charles'], ['Uncle John'], ['Mrs. Denham'], ['Mrs. Denham'], ['Mrs. Denham'], ['Charles'], ['Mrs. Denham'], ['Mrs. Denham']]]

qTextArr: ['That s simply not true,']
qText: That s simply not true,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['No. I thought not. But she won t believe me when I say it.']
qText: No. I thought not. But she won t believe me when I say it.
speaker: Joan

qTextArr: ['I m not interrupting?']
qText: I m not interrupting?
speaker: Joan

qTextArr: ['She doesn t understand that one s got to take risks,']
qText: She doesn t understand that one s got to take risks,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['I believe mother would take risks if she knew that Charles was the\nsort of boy to profit by it.']
qText:
I believe mother would take risks if she knew that Charles was the
sort of boy to profit by it.
speaker: Joan

qTextArr: ['He s got brains, hasn t he?']
qText: He s got brains, hasn t he?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['In some ways he s fearfully backward, though, compared with what you\nwere at his age. And he s difficult at home, too. He makes Molly slave\nfor him.']
qText:
In some ways he s fearfully backward, though, compared with what you
were at his age. And he s difficult at home, too. He makes Molly slave
for him.
speaker: Joan

qText: she,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['It s pretty hard lines to stick a boy into an office at seventeen!']
qText: It s pretty hard lines to stick a boy into an office at seventeen!
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Nobody _wants_ to stick him into an office,']
qText: Nobody _wants_ to stick him into an office,
speaker: Joan

qTextArr: ['The truth is,', 'that I ought to have accepted\nUncle John s offer. I should have been making six hundred a year by\nthis time.']
qText:
The truth is, that I ought to have accepted
Uncle John s offer. I should have been making six hundred a year by
this time.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['I don t think that for a moment,', 'The question, to my mind, is, whether we couldn t cut\ndown our expenses in some way.']
qText:
I don t think that for a moment, The question, to my mind, is, whether we couldn t cut
down our expenses in some way.
speaker: Joan

qTextArr: ['A smaller house?']
qText: A smaller house?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Fewer servants, perhaps.']
qText: Fewer servants, perhaps.
speaker: Joan

qTextArr: ['It s out of the question.']
qText: It s out of the question.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['If mother won t run risks']
qText: If mother won t run risks
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['You really can t expect her to sell out again.']
qText: You really can t expect her to sell out again.
speaker: Joan

qTextArr: ['She ought to look upon it as an investment; but if she won t, we must\nfind some other way, that s all.']
qText:
She ought to look upon it as an investment; but if she won t, we must
find some other way, that s all.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['I think you d be foolish to risk your money on poor old Charles,', 'Fond as I am of him, he doesn t seem to me exactly\nbrilliant.... Besides, why should you be sacrificed?']
qText:
I think you d be foolish to risk your money on poor old Charles, Fond as I am of him, he doesn t seem to me exactly
brilliant.... Besides, why should you be sacrificed?
speaker: Joan

qTextArr:
['My dear Joan,', 'don t you see that we ve all got to be sacrificed?
What s the use of denying it? What s the use of struggling against it?
So it always has been, so it always will be. We ve got no money and we
never shall have any money. We shall just turn round in the mill every
day of our lives until we drop and die, worn out, as most people do,
when one comes to think of it.']
qText:
My dear Joan, don t you see that we ve all got to be sacrificed?
What s the use of denying it? What s the use of struggling against it?
So it always has been, so it always will be. We ve got no money and we
never shall have any money. We shall just turn round in the mill every
day of our lives until we drop and die, worn out, as most people do,
when one comes to think of it.
speaker: Ralph Denham

we could take a jaunt to Italy. They say Switzerland s very lovely in
the snow, except for the cold. But, as you say, the great thing is to
finish the book. Now let me see']

finish the book. Now let me see

qTextArr:
['Ah!', 'why can t one say how beautiful it all is? Why am I condemned for
ever, Katharine, to feel what I can t express? And the things I can
give there s no use in my giving. Trust me, Katharine,', 'I won t speak of it again. But in the presence of beauty look
at the iridescence round the moon! one feels one feels Perhaps if you
married me I m half a poet, you see, and I can t pretend not to feel
what I do feel. If I could write ah, that would be another matter. I
shouldn t bother you to marry me then, Katharine.']
qText:
Ah! why can t one say how beautiful it all is? Why am I condemned for
ever, Katharine, to feel what I can t express? And the things I can
give there s no use in my giving. Trust me, Katharine, I won t speak of it again. But in the presence of beauty look
at the iridescence round the moon! one feels one feels Perhaps if you
married me I m half a poet, you see, and I can t pretend not to feel
what I do feel. If I could write ah, that would be another matter. I

qTextArr: ['I ve been told a great many unpleasant things about myself to-night,', 'Mr. Denham seems to think\nit his mission to lecture me, though I hardly know him. By the way,\nWilliam, you know him; tell me, what is he like?']
qText:
I ve been told a great many unpleasant things about myself to-night, Mr. Denham seems to think
it his mission to lecture me, though I hardly know him. By the way,
William, you know him; tell me, what is he like?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

menEnts: [[['Ralph Denham'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']], [['Ralph Denham'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham']]]

qTextArr:
['What happens with Mr. Denham is this: He comes to tea. I do all I can
to put him at his ease. He merely sits and scowls at me. Then I show
him our manuscripts. At this he becomes really angry, and tells me I ve
no business to call myself a middle-class woman. So we part in a huff;
and next time we meet, which was to-night, he walks straight up to me,
and says,  Go to the Devil!  That s the sort of behavior my mother
complains of. I want to know, what does it mean?']
qText:
What happens with Mr. Denham is this: He comes to tea. I do all I can
to put him at his ease. He merely sits and scowls at me. Then I show
him our manuscripts. At this he becomes really angry, and tells me I ve
no business to call myself a middle-class woman. So we part in a huff;
and next time we meet, which was to-night, he walks straight up to me,
and says,  Go to the Devil!  That s the sort of behavior my mother
complains of. I want to know, what does it mean?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['Of all the unreasonable, inconsiderate creatures I ve ever known,
she s the worst!', 'Heaven forbid that I should ever make a fool of myself
with her again. Why, I d sooner marry the daughter of my landlady than
Katharine Hilbery! She d leave me not a moment s peace and she d never
understand me never, never, never!']
qText:
Of all the unreasonable, inconsiderate creatures I ve ever known,
she s the worst! Heaven forbid that I should ever make a fool of myself
with her again. Why, I d sooner marry the daughter of my landlady than
Katharine Hilbery! She d leave me not a moment s peace and she d never
understand me never, never, never!
speaker: William Rodney

qText: Ha!
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr:
['You do well, Denham,', 'to have nothing to do
with young women. I offer you my experience if one trusts them one
invariably has cause to repent. Not that I have any reason at this
moment,', 'to complain of them. It s a subject that
crops up now and again for no particular reason. Miss Datchet, I dare
say, is one of the exceptions. Do you like Miss Datchet?']
qText:
You do well, Denham, to have nothing to do
with young women. I offer you my experience if one trusts them one
invariably has cause to repent. Not that I have any reason at this
moment, to complain of them. It s a subject that
crops up now and again for no particular reason. Miss Datchet, I dare
say, is one of the exceptions. Do you like Miss Datchet?
speaker: William Rodney

qText: Yes, I like Mary; I don t see how one could help liking her,

qTextArr:
['Ah, Denham, you re so different from me. You never give yourself away.
I watched you this evening with Katharine Hilbery. My instinct is to
trust the person I m talking to. That s why I m always being taken in,
I suppose.']
qText:
Ah, Denham, you re so different from me. You never give yourself away.
I watched you this evening with Katharine Hilbery. My instinct is to
trust the person I m talking to. That s why I m always being taken in,
I suppose.
speaker: William Rodney

Denham, I have no illusions about that young woman. I think I made that

qTextArr:
['You must not think that I have any bitterness against her far
from it. It s not altogether her fault, poor girl. She lives, you know,
one of those odious, self-centered lives at least, I think them odious
for a woman feeding her wits upon everything, having control of
everything, getting far too much her own way at home spoilt, in a
sense, feeling that every one is at her feet, and so not realizing how
she hurts that is, how rudely she behaves to people who haven t all her
advantages. Still, to do her justice, she s no fool,', 'She has taste. She has
sense. She can understand you when you talk to her. But she s a woman,
and there s an end of it,']
qText:
You must not think that I have any bitterness against her far
from it. It s not altogether her fault, poor girl. She lives, you know,
one of those odious, self-centered lives at least, I think them odious
for a woman feeding her wits upon everything, having control of
everything, getting far too much her own way at home spoilt, in a
sense, feeling that every one is at her feet, and so not realizing how
she hurts that is, how rudely she behaves to people who haven t all her
advantages. Still, to do her justice, she s no fool, She has taste. She has
sense. She can understand you when you talk to her. But she s a woman,

['There are one or two people I m fond of, and there s a little good

got a few nice things up here, things I pick up cheap, for I can t
afford to give what they ask.']

qTextArr:
['I m sorry, I m sorry,', 'It s my misfortune to be
an enthusiast,', 'My father s daughter
could hardly be anything else. I think I ve been on as many committees
as most people. Waifs and Strays, Rescue Work, Church Work, C. O.
S. local branch besides the usual civic duties which fall to one as a
householder. But I ve given them all up for our work here, and I don t
regret it for a second,', 'This is the root question, I feel;
until women have votes']
qText:
I m sorry, I m sorry, It s my misfortune to be
an enthusiast, My father s daughter
could hardly be anything else. I think I ve been on as many committees
as most people. Waifs and Strays, Rescue Work, Church Work, C. O.
S. local branch besides the usual civic duties which fall to one as a
householder. But I ve given them all up for our work here, and I don t
regret it for a second, This is the root question, I feel;
until women have votes
speaker: Mrs. Seal

qTextArr: ['It ll be sixpence, at least, Sally,', 'And we re all sick to death of women and their votes.']
qText: It ll be sixpence, at least, Sally, And we re all sick to death of women and their votes.
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['She s doing more for the cause than any of us. She s giving her\nyouth for, alas! when I was young there were domestic circumstances']
qText:
She s doing more for the cause than any of us. She s giving her
youth for, alas! when I was young there were domestic circumstances
speaker: Mrs. Seal
refExp: she remarked rather confidentially to Katharine

qTextArr:
['Yes, I took my little bag into the square,', 'It
was really very sustaining, and the bare boughs against the sky do one
so much _good_. But I shall have to give up going into the square,', 'The injustice of it! Why should I
have a beautiful square all to myself, when poor women who need rest
have nowhere at all to sit?', 'It s dreadful what a tyrant one still
is, in spite of all one s efforts. One tries to lead a decent life, but
one can t. Of course, directly one thinks of it, one sees that _all_
squares should be open to _every one_. Is there any society with that
object, Mr. Clacton? If not, there should be, surely.']
qText:
Yes, I took my little bag into the square, It
was really very sustaining, and the bare boughs against the sky do one
so much _good_. But I shall have to give up going into the square, The injustice of it! Why should I
have a beautiful square all to myself, when poor women who need rest
have nowhere at all to sit? It s dreadful what a tyrant one still
is, in spite of all one s efforts. One tries to lead a decent life, but
one can t. Of course, directly one thinks of it, one sees that _all_
squares should be open to _every one_. Is there any society with that
object, Mr. Clacton? If not, there should be, surely.
speaker: Mrs. Seal

qTextArr:
['A most excellent object,', 'At the same time, one must deplore the ramification of organizations,
Mrs. Seal. So much excellent effort thrown away, not to speak of
pounds, shillings, and pence. Now how many organizations of a
philanthropic nature do you suppose there are in the City of London
itself, Miss Hilbery?']
qText:
A most excellent object, At the same time, one must deplore the ramification of organizations,
Mrs. Seal. So much excellent effort thrown away, not to speak of
pounds, shillings, and pence. Now how many organizations of a
philanthropic nature do you suppose there are in the City of London
itself, Miss Hilbery?
speaker: Mr. Clacton

['Mrs. Seal is an enthusiast in these matters,', 'We have to remind her sometimes that others have a
right to their views even if they differ from our own....', 'has a
very funny picture this week, about a Suffragist and an agricultural
laborer. Have you seen this week s', 'Miss Datchet?']
qText:
Mrs. Seal is an enthusiast in these matters, We have to remind her sometimes that others have a
right to their views even if they differ from our own.... has a
very funny picture this week, about a Suffragist and an agricultural
laborer. Have you seen this week s Miss Datchet?
speaker: Mr. Clacton
menEnts: [[['Mrs. Seal']], [['Mary Datchet', 'Mr. Clacton'], ['Mrs. Seal']], [['Mary Datchet']], [['Mary Datchet']]]

qText: No.
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['But surely, if you care about the welfare of your sex at all, you must\nwish them to have the vote?']
qText:
But surely, if you care about the welfare of your sex at all, you must
wish them to have the vote?
speaker: Mrs. Seal

qTextArr: ['I never said I didn t wish them to have the vote,']
qText: I never said I didn t wish them to have the vote,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Then why aren t you a member of our society?']
qText: Then why aren t you a member of our society?
speaker: Mrs. Seal

qTextArr: ['Are you in any way related, I wonder, to the poet Alardyce? His\ndaughter, I believe, married a Mr. Hilbery.']
qText:
Are you in any way related, I wonder, to the poet Alardyce? His
daughter, I believe, married a Mr. Hilbery.
speaker: Mr. Clacton
refExp: Mr Clacton meanwhile framed a question which after a moment s hesitation he put to Katharine

qTextArr: ['Yes; I m the poet s granddaughter,']
qText: Yes; I m the poet s granddaughter,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['The poet s granddaughter!']
qText: The poet s granddaughter!
speaker: Mrs. Seal

qTextArr:
['Ah, indeed. That interests me very much,', 'I owe a great debt
to your grandfather, Miss Hilbery. At one time I could have repeated
the greater part of him by heart. But one gets out of the way of
reading poetry, unfortunately. You don t remember him, I suppose?']
qText:
Ah, indeed. That interests me very much, I owe a great debt
to your grandfather, Miss Hilbery. At one time I could have repeated
the greater part of him by heart. But one gets out of the way of
reading poetry, unfortunately. You don t remember him, I suppose?
speaker: Mr. Clacton

qTextArr: ['The proofs at last!']
qText: The proofs at last!
speaker: Mrs. Seal
refExp: Mrs Seal looked up with renewed hope in her eyes and exclaiming

qTextArr: ['Oh, it s only Mr. Denham!']
qText: Oh, it s only Mr. Denham!
speaker: Mrs. Seal

qTextArr: ['Katharine has come to see how one runs an office.']
qText: Katharine has come to see how one runs an office.
speaker: Mary Datchet
refExp: Mary at once explained the strange fact of her being there by saying

qTextArr: ['I hope Mary hasn t persuaded you that she knows how to run an office?']
qText: I hope Mary hasn t persuaded you that she knows how to run an office?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['What, doesn t she?']
qText: What, doesn t she?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['Now, I know what you re going to say, Mr. Denham! But it was the day
Kit Markham was here, and she upsets one so with her wonderful
vitality, always thinking of something new that we ought to be doing
and aren t and I was conscious at the time that my dates were mixed. It
had nothing to do with Mary at all, I assure you.']
qText:
Now, I know what you re going to say, Mr. Denham! But it was the day
Kit Markham was here, and she upsets one so with her wonderful
vitality, always thinking of something new that we ought to be doing
and aren t and I was conscious at the time that my dates were mixed. It
had nothing to do with Mary at all, I assure you.
speaker: Mrs. Seal

qTextArr: ['My dear Sally, don t apologize,', 'Men are such\npedants they don t know what things matter, and what things don t.']
qText:
My dear Sally, don t apologize, Men are such
pedants they don t know what things matter, and what things don t.
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['Now, Denham, speak up for our sex,']
qText: Now, Denham, speak up for our sex,
speaker: Mr. Clacton

qTextArr:
['Doesn t it seem strange to you, Miss Hilbery,', 'that the
French, with all their wealth of illustrious names, have no poet who
can compare with your grandfather? Let me see. There s Chenier and Hugo
and Alfred de Musset wonderful men, but, at the same time, there s a
richness, a freshness about Alardyce']
qText:
Doesn t it seem strange to you, Miss Hilbery, that the
French, with all their wealth of illustrious names, have no poet who
can compare with your grandfather? Let me see. There s Chenier and Hugo
and Alfred de Musset wonderful men, but, at the same time, there s a
richness, a freshness about Alardyce
speaker: Mr. Clacton

qTextArr:
['For if I were to tell you what I know of back-stairs
intrigue, and what can be done by the power of the purse, you wouldn t
credit me, Mr. Denham, you wouldn t, indeed. Which is why I feel that
the only work for my father s daughter for he was one of the pioneers,
Mr. Denham, and on his tombstone I had that verse from the Psalms put,
about the sowers and the seed.... And what wouldn t I give that he
should be alive now, seeing what we re going to see']
qText:
For if I were to tell you what I know of back-stairs
intrigue, and what can be done by the power of the purse, you wouldn t
credit me, Mr. Denham, you wouldn t, indeed. Which is why I feel that
the only work for my father s daughter for he was one of the pioneers,
Mr. Denham, and on his tombstone I had that verse from the Psalms put,
about the sowers and the seed.... And what wouldn t I give that he
should be alive now, seeing what we re going to see
speaker: Mrs. Seal

qTextArr:
['The standard of morality seems to me frightfully low,', 'especially among women
who aren t well educated. They don t see that small things matter, and
that s where the leakage begins, and then we find ourselves in
difficulties I very nearly lost my temper yesterday,']
qText:
The standard of morality seems to me frightfully low, especially among women
who aren t well educated. They don t see that small things matter, and
that s where the leakage begins, and then we find ourselves in
difficulties I very nearly lost my temper yesterday,
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['It makes me very angry when people tell me\nlies doesn t it make you angry?']
qText:
It makes me very angry when people tell me
lies doesn t it make you angry?
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['But considering that every one tells lies,']
qText: But considering that every one tells lies,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I don t think that I tell lies, and I don t think that Ralph tells\nlies, do you, Ralph?']
qText:
I don t think that I tell lies, and I don t think that Ralph tells
lies, do you, Ralph?
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['Mary Datchet does that sort of work very well.... She s responsible\nfor it, I suppose?']
qText:
Mary Datchet does that sort of work very well.... She s responsible
for it, I suppose?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Yes. The others don t help at all.... Has she made a convert of you?']
qText: Yes. The others don t help at all.... Has she made a convert of you?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Oh no. That is, I m a convert already.']
qText: Oh no. That is, I m a convert already.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['But she hasn t persuaded you to work for them?']
qText: But she hasn t persuaded you to work for them?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Oh dear no that wouldn t do at all.']
qText: Oh dear no that wouldn t do at all.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Suppose we get on to that omnibus?']
qText: Suppose we get on to that omnibus?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['But which way are you going?']
qText: But which way are you going?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I m going to the Temple,']
qText: I m going to the Temple,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['This is like Venice,', 'The motor-cars,\nI mean, shooting about so quickly, with their lights.']
qText:
This is like Venice, The motor-cars,
I mean, shooting about so quickly, with their lights.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I ve never seen Venice,', 'I keep that and some other\nthings for my old age.']
qText:
I ve never seen Venice, I keep that and some other
things for my old age.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['What are the other things?']
qText: What are the other things?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['There s Venice and India and, I think, Dante, too.']
qText: There s Venice and India and, I think, Dante, too.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Think of providing for one s old age! And would you refuse to see\nVenice if you had the chance?']
qText:
Think of providing for one s old age! And would you refuse to see
Venice if you had the chance?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I ve planned out my life in sections ever since I was a child, to make\nit last longer. You see, I m always afraid that I m missing something']
qText:
I ve planned out my life in sections ever since I was a child, to make
it last longer. You see, I m always afraid that I m missing something
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['And so am I!']
qText: And so am I!
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['But, after all,', 'why\nshould you miss anything?']
qText:
But, after all, why
should you miss anything?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Why? Because I m poor, for one thing,', 'You, I\nsuppose, can have Venice and India and Dante every day of your life.']
qText:
Why? Because I m poor, for one thing, You, I
suppose, can have Venice and India and Dante every day of your life.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['But to know that one might have things doesn t alter the fact that one\nhasn t got them,', 'How could I go to\nIndia, for example? Besides,']
qText:
But to know that one might have things doesn t alter the fact that one
hasn t got them, How could I go to
India, for example? Besides,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I have a message to give your father,', 'Perhaps you would\ngive it him, or I could come']
qText:
I have a message to give your father, Perhaps you would
give it him, or I could come
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Yes, do come,']
qText: Yes, do come,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Still, I don t see why you shouldn t go to India,']
qText: Still, I don t see why you shouldn t go to India,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['And little Augustus Pelham said to me,']
qText: And little Augustus Pelham said to me,
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['and I said to him,']
qText: and I said to him,
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Such a feeble little\njoke, wasn t it, but down it went into his notebook all the same."']
qText:
Such a feeble little
joke, wasn t it, but down it went into his notebook all the same."
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Let us congratulate ourselves that we shall be in the grave before\nthat work is published,']
qText:
Let us congratulate ourselves that we shall be in the grave before
that work is published,
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['The only excuse for you, Katharine, is that dinner is still later than\nyou are,']
qText:
The only excuse for you, Katharine, is that dinner is still later than
you are,
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I don t mind her being late when the result is so charming,', 'Still, I don t know that\nI _like_ your being out so late, Katharine,', 'You took a\ncab, I hope?']
qText:
I don t mind her being late when the result is so charming, Still, I don t know that
I _like_ your being out so late, Katharine, You took a
cab, I hope?
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['That s more cheerful,', 'D you know, Katharine, that
ridiculous goose came to tea with me? Oh, how I wanted you! He tried to
make epigrams all the time, and I got so nervous, expecting them, you
know, that I spilt the tea and he made an epigram about that!']
qText:
That s more cheerful, D you know, Katharine, that
ridiculous goose came to tea with me? Oh, how I wanted you! He tried to
make epigrams all the time, and I got so nervous, expecting them, you
know, that I spilt the tea and he made an epigram about that!
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Which ridiculous goose?']
qText: Which ridiculous goose?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Only one of my geese, happily, makes epigrams Augustus Pelham, of\ncourse,']
qText:
Only one of my geese, happily, makes epigrams Augustus Pelham, of
course,
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I m not sorry that I was out,']
qText: I m not sorry that I was out,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Poor Augustus!', 'But we re all too hard on\nhim. Remember how devoted he is to his tiresome old mother.']
qText:
Poor Augustus! But we re all too hard on
him. Remember how devoted he is to his tiresome old mother.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['That s only because she is his mother. Any one connected with\nhimself']
qText:
That s only because she is his mother. Any one connected with
himself
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['No, no, Katharine that s too bad. That s what s the word I mean,\nTrevor, something long and Latin the sort of word you and Katharine\nknow']
qText:
No, no, Katharine that s too bad. That s what s the word I mean,
Trevor, something long and Latin the sort of word you and Katharine
know
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['cynical.']
qText: cynical.
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['Well, that ll do. I don t believe in sending girls to college, but I
should teach them that sort of thing. It makes one feel so dignified,
bringing out these little allusions, and passing on gracefully to the
next topic. But I don t know what s come over me I actually had to ask
Augustus the name of the lady Hamlet was in love with, as you were out,
Katharine, and Heaven knows what he mayn t put down about me in his
diary.']
qText:
Well, that ll do. I don t believe in sending girls to college, but I
should teach them that sort of thing. It makes one feel so dignified,
bringing out these little allusions, and passing on gracefully to the
next topic. But I don t know what s come over me I actually had to ask
Augustus the name of the lady Hamlet was in love with, as you were out,
Katharine, and Heaven knows what he mayn t put down about me in his
diary.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I wish,']
qText: I wish,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['What is it you wish?']
qText: What is it you wish?
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I wish mother wasn t famous. I was out at tea, and they would talk to\nme about poetry.']
qText:
I wish mother wasn t famous. I was out at tea, and they would talk to
me about poetry.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Thinking you must be poetical, I see and aren t you?']
qText: Thinking you must be poetical, I see and aren t you?
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Who s been talking to you about poetry, Katharine?']
qText: Who s been talking to you about poetry, Katharine?
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['They have an office at the top of one of the old houses in Russell
Square. I never saw such queer-looking people. And the man discovered I
was related to the poet, and talked to me about poetry. Even Mary
Datchet seems different in that atmosphere.']
qText:
They have an office at the top of one of the old houses in Russell
Square. I never saw such queer-looking people. And the man discovered I
was related to the poet, and talked to me about poetry. Even Mary
Datchet seems different in that atmosphere.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Yes, the office atmosphere is very bad for the soul,']
qText: Yes, the office atmosphere is very bad for the soul,
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['I don t remember any offices in Russell Square in the old days, when
Mamma lived there,', 'and I can t fancy turning one
of those noble great rooms into a stuffy little Suffrage office. Still,
if the clerks read poetry there must be something nice about them.']
qText:
I don t remember any offices in Russell Square in the old days, when
Mamma lived there, and I can t fancy turning one
of those noble great rooms into a stuffy little Suffrage office. Still,
if the clerks read poetry there must be something nice about them.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['No, because they don t read it as we read it,']
qText: No, because they don t read it as we read it,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
menEnts: [[['Mrs. Seal', 'Mary Datchet', 'Mr. Clacton'], ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery']]]

qTextArr: ['But it s nice to think of them reading your grandfather, and not\nfilling up those dreadful little forms all day long,']
qText:
But it s nice to think of them reading your grandfather, and not
filling up those dreadful little forms all day long,
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['At any rate, they haven t made a convert of Katharine, which was what\nI was afraid of,']
qText:
At any rate, they haven t made a convert of Katharine, which was what
I was afraid of,
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Oh no,', 'I wouldn t work with them for\nanything.']
qText:
Oh no, I wouldn t work with them for
anything.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['It s curious,', 'how
the sight of one s fellow-enthusiasts always chokes one off. They show
up the faults of one s cause so much more plainly than one s
antagonists. One can be enthusiastic in one s study, but directly one
comes into touch with the people who agree with one, all the glamor
goes. So I ve always found,']
qText:
It s curious, how
the sight of one s fellow-enthusiasts always chokes one off. They show
up the faults of one s cause so much more plainly than one s
antagonists. One can be enthusiastic in one s study, but directly one
comes into touch with the people who agree with one, all the glamor
goes. So I ve always found,
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['Oh, Katharine,', 'how you ve made me think of Mamma and
the old days in Russell Square! I can see the chandeliers, and the
green silk of the piano, and Mamma sitting in her cashmere shawl by the
window, singing till the little ragamuffin boys outside stopped to
listen. Papa sent me in with a bunch of violets while he waited round
the corner. It must have been a summer evening. That was before things
were hopeless....']
qText:
Oh, Katharine, how you ve made me think of Mamma and
the old days in Russell Square! I can see the chandeliers, and the
green silk of the piano, and Mamma sitting in her cashmere shawl by the
window, singing till the little ragamuffin boys outside stopped to
listen. Papa sent me in with a bunch of violets while he waited round
the corner. It must have been a summer evening. That was before things
were hopeless....
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['If they d lived now,', 'I feel it wouldn t have
happened. People aren t so set upon tragedy as they were then. If my
father had been able to go round the world, or if she d had a rest
cure, everything would have come right. But what could I do? And then
they had bad friends, both of them, who made mischief. Ah, Katharine,
when you marry, be quite, quite sure that you love your husband!']
qText:
If they d lived now, I feel it wouldn t have
happened. People aren t so set upon tragedy as they were then. If my
father had been able to go round the world, or if she d had a rest
cure, everything would have come right. But what could I do? And then
they had bad friends, both of them, who made mischief. Ah, Katharine,
when you marry, be quite, quite sure that you love your husband!
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
menEnts: [[['Richard Alardyce']], [['Richard Alardyce'], ['Richard Alardyce'], ['Richard Alardyce'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

qTextArr:
['Now this is what
Mary Datchet and Mr. Denham don t understand. This is the sort of
position I m always getting into. How simple it must be to live as they
do!']
qText:
Now this is what
Mary Datchet and Mr. Denham don t understand. This is the sort of
position I m always getting into. How simple it must be to live as they
do!
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['But, Katharine,', 'though, Heaven knows, I don t want to see you
married, surely if ever a man loved a woman, William loves you. And
it s a nice, rich-sounding name too Katharine Rodney, which,
unfortunately, doesn t mean that he s got any money, because he
hasn t.']
qText:
But, Katharine, though, Heaven knows, I don t want to see you
married, surely if ever a man loved a woman, William loves you. And
it s a nice, rich-sounding name too Katharine Rodney, which,
unfortunately, doesn t mean that he s got any money, because he
hasn t.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
menEnts: [[['Katharine Hilbery']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['William Rodney'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['William Rodney']]]

qTextArr: ['It s very dull that you can only marry one husband, certainly,', 'I always wish that you could marry everybody who\nwants to marry you. Perhaps they ll come to that in time, but meanwhile\nI confess that dear William']
qText:
It s very dull that you can only marry one husband, certainly, I always wish that you could marry everybody who
wants to marry you. Perhaps they ll come to that in time, but meanwhile
I confess that dear William
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Please, Katharine, read us something _real_.']
qText: Please, Katharine, read us something _real_.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['What would Ralph Denham say to this?']
qText: What would Ralph Denham say to this?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['What would Mary Datchet and Ralph Denham say?']
qText: What would Mary Datchet and Ralph Denham say?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I ve had a letter from Aunt Celia about Cyril, father.... It seems to\nbe true about his marriage. What are we to do?']
qText:
I ve had a letter from Aunt Celia about Cyril, father.... It seems to
be true about his marriage. What are we to do?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Cyril seems to have been behaving in a very foolish manner,']
qText: Cyril seems to have been behaving in a very foolish manner,
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['He s about done for himself, I should say,']
qText: He s about done for himself, I should say,
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Humph!']
qText: Humph!
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Mother knows nothing about it,', 'Will you tell\nher?']
qText:
Mother knows nothing about it, Will you tell
her?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I shall tell your mother. But I shall tell her that there is nothing\nwhatever for us to do.']
qText:
I shall tell your mother. But I shall tell her that there is nothing
whatever for us to do.
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['But the marriage?']
qText: But the marriage?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['What in the name of conscience did he do it for?']
qText: What in the name of conscience did he do it for?
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Well, if the younger generation want to carry on its life on those\nlines, it s none of our affair,']
qText:
Well, if the younger generation want to carry on its life on those
lines, it s none of our affair,
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['But isn t it our affair, perhaps, to make them get married?']
qText: But isn t it our affair, perhaps, to make them get married?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Why the dickens should they apply to me?']
qText: Why the dickens should they apply to me?
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Only as the head of the family']
qText: Only as the head of the family
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['But I m not the head of the family. Alfred s the head of the family.\nLet them apply to Alfred,']
qText:
But I m not the head of the family. Alfred s the head of the family.
Let them apply to Alfred,
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I think, perhaps, the best thing would be for me to go and see them,']
qText: I think, perhaps, the best thing would be for me to go and see them,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I won t have you going anywhere near them,', 'Indeed, I don t understand why\nthey ve dragged you into the business at all I don t see that it s got\nanything to do with you.']
qText:
I won t have you going anywhere near them, Indeed, I don t understand why
they ve dragged you into the business at all I don t see that it s got
anything to do with you.
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I ve always been friends with Cyril,']
qText: I ve always been friends with Cyril,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['But did he ever tell you anything about this?']
qText: But did he ever tell you anything about this?
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['As to your mother,', 'you had better tell
her the facts. She d better know the facts before every one begins to
talk about it, though why Aunt Celia thinks it necessary to come, I m
sure I don t know. And the less talk there is the better.']
qText:
As to your mother, you had better tell
her the facts. She d better know the facts before every one begins to
talk about it, though why Aunt Celia thinks it necessary to come, I m
sure I don t know. And the less talk there is the better.
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Have you told mother?']
qText: Have you told mother?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['My dear child, it went out of my head.']
qText: My dear child, it went out of my head.
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I ll send a note\nround from the office.... I m late this morning, and I ve any amount of\nproofs to get through.']
qText:
I ll send a note
round from the office.... I m late this morning, and I ve any amount of
proofs to get through.
speaker: Mr. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['That wouldn t do at all,', 'She must be\ntold you or I must tell her. We ought to have told her at first.']
qText:
That wouldn t do at all, She must be
told you or I must tell her. We ought to have told her at first.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
menEnts: [[], [['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mr. Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Mr. Hilbery', 'Katharine Hilbery'], ['Mrs. Hilbery']]]

qTextArr:
['Katharine,', 'I ve just made out such
a queer, strange thing about your grandfather. I m three years and six
months older than he was when he died. I couldn t very well have been
his mother, but I might have been his elder sister, and that seems to
me such a pleasant fancy. I m going to start quite fresh this morning,
and get a lot done.']
qText:
Katharine, I ve just made out such
a queer, strange thing about your grandfather. I m three years and six
months older than he was when he died. I couldn t very well have been
his mother, but I might have been his elder sister, and that seems to
me such a pleasant fancy. I m going to start quite fresh this morning,
and get a lot done.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I really believe I m bewitched! I only want three sentences, you see,\nsomething quite straightforward and commonplace, and I can t find  em.']
qText:
I really believe I m bewitched! I only want three sentences, you see,
something quite straightforward and commonplace, and I can t find  em.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
refExp: Mrs Hilbery turned abruptly and exclaimed

qTextArr:
['Besides,', 'I
don t believe this ll do. Did your grandfather ever visit the Hebrides,
Katharine?', 'My mind got running on the Hebrides, and I couldn t help writing a
little description of them. Perhaps it would do at the beginning of a
chapter. Chapters often begin quite differently from the way they go
on, you know.']
qText:
Besides, I
don t believe this ll do. Did your grandfather ever visit the Hebrides,
Katharine? My mind got running on the Hebrides, and I couldn t help writing a
little description of them. Perhaps it would do at the beginning of a
chapter. Chapters often begin quite differently from the way they go
on, you know.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['It s very beautiful,', 'but, you see, mother, we ought to\ngo from point to point']
qText:
It s very beautiful, but, you see, mother, we ought to
go from point to point
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['Oh, I know,', 'And that s just what I can t do.
Things keep coming into my head. It isn t that I don t know everything
and feel everything (who did know him, if I didn t?), but I can t put
it down, you see. There s a kind of blind spot,', 'there. And when I can t sleep o  nights, I fancy I shall die
without having done it.']
qText:
Oh, I know, And that s just what I can t do.
Things keep coming into my head. It isn t that I don t know everything
and feel everything (who did know him, if I didn t?), but I can t put
it down, you see. There s a kind of blind spot, there. And when I can t sleep o  nights, I fancy I shall die
without having done it.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['Surely, Katharine,', 'the men were far handsomer in those
days than they are now, in spite of their odious whiskers? Look at old
John Graham, in his white waistcoat look at Uncle Harley. That s Peter
the manservant, I suppose. Uncle John brought him back from India.']
qText:
Surely, Katharine, the men were far handsomer in those
days than they are now, in spite of their odious whiskers? Look at old
John Graham, in his white waistcoat look at Uncle Harley. That s Peter
the manservant, I suppose. Uncle John brought him back from India.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['What is nobler,', 'than to be
a woman to whom every one turns, in sorrow or difficulty? How have the
young women of your generation improved upon that, Katharine? I can see
them now, sweeping over the lawns at Melbury House, in their flounces
and furbelows, so calm and stately and imperial (and the monkey and the
little black dwarf following behind), as if nothing mattered in the
world but to be beautiful and kind. But they did more than we do, I
sometimes think. They WERE, and that s better than doing. They seem to
me like ships, like majestic ships, holding on their way, not shoving
or pushing, not fretted by little things, as we are, but taking their
way, like ships with white sails.']
qText:
What is nobler, than to be
a woman to whom every one turns, in sorrow or difficulty? How have the
young women of your generation improved upon that, Katharine? I can see
them now, sweeping over the lawns at Melbury House, in their flounces
and furbelows, so calm and stately and imperial (and the monkey and the
little black dwarf following behind), as if nothing mattered in the
world but to be beautiful and kind. But they did more than we do, I
sometimes think. They WERE, and that s better than doing. They seem to
me like ships, like majestic ships, holding on their way, not shoving
or pushing, not fretted by little things, as we are, but taking their
way, like ships with white sails.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery
menEnts: [[], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery', 'Mrs. Hilbery', 'Mr. Hilbery']]]

qTextArr:
['That s Janie Mannering,', 'I must have told
you how she found her cook drunk under the kitchen table when the
Empress was coming to dinner, and tucked up her velvet sleeves (she
always dressed like an Empress herself), cooked the whole meal, and
appeared in the drawing-room as if she d been sleeping on a bank of
roses all day. She could do anything with her hands they all could make
a cottage or embroider a petticoat.']
qText:
That s Janie Mannering, I must have told
you how she found her cook drunk under the kitchen table when the
Empress was coming to dinner, and tucked up her velvet sleeves (she
always dressed like an Empress herself), cooked the whole meal, and
appeared in the drawing-room as if she d been sleeping on a bank of
roses all day. She could do anything with her hands they all could make
a cottage or embroider a petticoat.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['And that s Queenie Colquhoun,', 'who
took her coffin out with her to Jamaica, packed with lovely shawls and
bonnets, because you couldn t get coffins in Jamaica, and she had a
horror of dying there (as she did), and being devoured by the white
ants. And there s Sabine, the loveliest of them all; ah! it was like a
star rising when she came into the room. And that s Miriam, in her
coachman s cloak, with all the little capes on, and she wore great
top-boots underneath. You young people may say you re unconventional,
but you re nothing compared with her.']
qText:
And that s Queenie Colquhoun, who
took her coffin out with her to Jamaica, packed with lovely shawls and
bonnets, because you couldn t get coffins in Jamaica, and she had a
horror of dying there (as she did), and being devoured by the white
ants. And there s Sabine, the loveliest of them all; ah! it was like a
star rising when she came into the room. And that s Miriam, in her
coachman s cloak, with all the little capes on, and she wore great
top-boots underneath. You young people may say you re unconventional,
but you re nothing compared with her.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['Ah, you wretch!', 'what a wicked old despot you
were, in your day! How we all bowed down before you!  Maggie,  she used
to say,  if it hadn t been for me, where would you be now?  And it was
true; she brought them together, you know. She said to my father,
 Marry her,  and he did; and she said to poor little Clara,  Fall down
and worship him,  and she did; but she got up again, of course. What
else could one expect? She was a mere child eighteen and half dead with
fright, too. But that old tyrant never repented. She used to say that
she had given them three perfect months, and no one had a right to
more; and I sometimes think, Katharine, that s true, you know. It s
more than most of us have, only we have to pretend, which was a thing
neither of them could ever do. I fancy,', 'that
there was a kind of sincerity in those days between men and women
which, with all your outspokenness, you haven t got.']
qText:
Ah, you wretch! what a wicked old despot you
were, in your day! How we all bowed down before you!  Maggie,  she used
to say,  if it hadn t been for me, where would you be now?  And it was
true; she brought them together, you know. She said to my father,
 Marry her,  and he did; and she said to poor little Clara,  Fall down
and worship him,  and she did; but she got up again, of course. What
else could one expect? She was a mere child eighteen and half dead with
fright, too. But that old tyrant never repented. She used to say that
she had given them three perfect months, and no one had a right to
more; and I sometimes think, Katharine, that s true, you know. It s
more than most of us have, only we have to pretend, which was a thing
neither of them could ever do. I fancy, that
there was a kind of sincerity in those days between men and women
which, with all your outspokenness, you haven t got.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['They must have been good friends at heart,', 'because she\nused to sing his songs. Ah, how did it go?']
qText:
They must have been good friends at heart, because she
used to sing his songs. Ah, how did it go?
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['It s the vitality of them!', 'That s what we haven t got! We re virtuous, we re earnest,
we go to meetings, we pay the poor their wages, but we don t live as
they lived. As often as not, my father wasn t in bed three nights out
of the seven, but always fresh as paint in the morning. I hear him now,
come singing up the stairs to the nursery, and tossing the loaf for
breakfast on his sword-stick, and then off we went for a day s
pleasuring Richmond, Hampton Court, the Surrey Hills. Why shouldn t we
go, Katharine? It s going to be a fine day.']
qText:
It s the vitality of them! That s what we haven t got! We re virtuous, we re earnest,
we go to meetings, we pay the poor their wages, but we don t live as
they lived. As often as not, my father wasn t in bed three nights out
of the seven, but always fresh as paint in the morning. I hear him now,
come singing up the stairs to the nursery, and tossing the loaf for
breakfast on his sword-stick, and then off we went for a day s
pleasuring Richmond, Hampton Court, the Surrey Hills. Why shouldn t we
go, Katharine? It s going to be a fine day.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Aunt\nCelia!']
qText:
Aunt
Celia!
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I think Aunt Celia has come to talk about Cyril, mother,', 'Aunt Celia has discovered that Cyril is married. He\nhas a wife and children.']
qText:
I think Aunt Celia has come to talk about Cyril, mother, Aunt Celia has discovered that Cyril is married. He
has a wife and children.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['No, he is _not_ married,', 'He has two children, and another\non the way.']
qText:
No, he is _not_ married, He has two children, and another
on the way.
speaker: Mrs. Milvain
refExp: Mrs Milvain interposed in low tones addressing herself to Mrs Hilbery

qTextArr: ['We thought it better to wait until it was proved before we told you,']
qText: We thought it better to wait until it was proved before we told you,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['But I met Cyril only a fortnight ago at the National Gallery!', 'I don t believe a word of it,']
qText: But I met Cyril only a fortnight ago at the National Gallery! I don t believe a word of it,
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I didn t _wish_ to believe it, Maggie,', 'For a long\ntime I _couldn t_ believe it. But now I ve seen, and I _have_ to\nbelieve it.']
qText:
I didn t _wish_ to believe it, Maggie, For a long
time I _couldn t_ believe it. But now I ve seen, and I _have_ to
believe it.
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

qTextArr: ['Katharine,', 'does your father know of this?']
qText: Katharine, does your father know of this?
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Cyril married!', 'And never telling us a word,\nthough we ve had him in our house since he was a child noble William s\nson! I can t believe my ears!']
qText:
Cyril married! And never telling us a word,
though we ve had him in our house since he was a child noble William s
son! I can t believe my ears!
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['I have suspected for some time that he was not happy. There were new
lines on his face. So I went to his rooms, when I knew he was engaged
at the poor men s college. He lectures there Roman law, you know, or it
may be Greek. The landlady said Mr. Alardyce only slept there about
once a fortnight now. He looked so ill, she said. She had seen him with
a young person. I suspected something directly. I went to his room, and
there was an envelope on the mantelpiece, and a letter with an address
in Seton Street, off the Kennington Road.']
qText:
I have suspected for some time that he was not happy. There were new
lines on his face. So I went to his rooms, when I knew he was engaged
at the poor men s college. He lectures there Roman law, you know, or it
may be Greek. The landlady said Mr. Alardyce only slept there about
once a fortnight now. He looked so ill, she said. She had seen him with
a young person. I suspected something directly. I went to his room, and
there was an envelope on the mantelpiece, and a letter with an address
in Seton Street, off the Kennington Road.
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

qTextArr:
['I went to Seton Street,', 'A very low
place lodging-houses, you know, with canaries in the window. Number
seven just like all the others. I rang, I knocked; no one came. I went
down the area. I am certain I saw some one inside children a cradle.
But no reply no reply.']
qText:
I went to Seton Street, A very low
place lodging-houses, you know, with canaries in the window. Number
seven just like all the others. I rang, I knocked; no one came. I went
down the area. I am certain I saw some one inside children a cradle.
But no reply no reply.
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

qTextArr:
['I stood in the street,', 'in case I could catch a sight of
one of them. It seemed a very long time. There were rough men singing
in the public-house round the corner. At last the door opened, and some
one it must have been the woman herself came right past me. There was
only the pillar-box between us.']
qText:
I stood in the street, in case I could catch a sight of
one of them. It seemed a very long time. There were rough men singing
in the public-house round the corner. At last the door opened, and some
one it must have been the woman herself came right past me. There was
only the pillar-box between us.
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

qTextArr: ['And what did she look like?']
qText: And what did she look like?
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['One could see how the poor boy had been deluded,']
qText: One could see how the poor boy had been deluded,
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

qTextArr: ['Poor thing!']
qText: Poor thing!

qTextArr: ['Poor Cyril!']
qText: Poor Cyril!
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

qTextArr:
['But they ve got nothing to live upon,', 'If
he d come to us like a man,', 'and said,  I ve been a
fool,  one would have pitied him; one would have tried to help him.
There s nothing so disgraceful after all But he s been going about all
these years, pretending, letting one take it for granted, that he was
single. And the poor deserted little wife']
qText:
But they ve got nothing to live upon, If
he d come to us like a man, and said,  I ve been a
fool,  one would have pitied him; one would have tried to help him.
There s nothing so disgraceful after all But he s been going about all
these years, pretending, letting one take it for granted, that he was

qText: She is _not_ his wife,
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

qTextArr: ['I ve never heard anything so detestable!']
qText: I ve never heard anything so detestable!
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['We must realize Cyril s point of view first,']
qText: We must realize Cyril s point of view first,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['This unhappy business,', 'If the
train had not gone out of the station just as I arrived, I should have
been with you before. Celia has doubtless told you. You will agree with
me, Maggie. He must be made to marry her at once for the sake of the
children']
qText:
This unhappy business, If the
train had not gone out of the station just as I arrived, I should have
been with you before. Celia has doubtless told you. You will agree with
me, Maggie. He must be made to marry her at once for the sake of the
children
speaker: Cousin Caroline

qTextArr: ['But does he refuse to marry her?']
qText: But does he refuse to marry her?
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['He has written an absurd perverted letter, all quotations,', 'He thinks he s doing a very fine thing, where we only\nsee the folly of it.... The girl s every bit as infatuated as he is for\nwhich I blame him.']
qText:
He has written an absurd perverted letter, all quotations, He thinks he s doing a very fine thing, where we only
see the folly of it.... The girl s every bit as infatuated as he is for
which I blame him.
speaker: Cousin Caroline

qTextArr: ['She entangled him,']
qText: She entangled him,
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

qTextArr:
['It s no use going into the rights and wrongs of the affair now,
Celia,', 'The
mischief s done, and very ugly mischief too. Are we to allow the third
child to be born out of wedlock? (I am sorry to have to say these
things before you, Katharine.) He will bear your name, Maggie your
father s name, remember.']
qText:
It s no use going into the rights and wrongs of the affair now,
Celia, The
mischief s done, and very ugly mischief too. Are we to allow the third
child to be born out of wedlock? (I am sorry to have to say these
things before you, Katharine.) He will bear your name, Maggie your
father s name, remember.
speaker: Cousin Caroline

qTextArr: ['But let us hope it will be a girl,']
qText: But let us hope it will be a girl,

qTextArr: ['It s detestable quite detestable!']
qText: It s detestable quite detestable!
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['Nowadays, people don t think so
badly of these things as they used to do,', 'It will be
horribly uncomfortable for them sometimes, but if they are brave,
clever children, as they will be, I dare say it ll make remarkable
people of them in the end. Robert Browning used to say that every great
man has Jewish blood in him, and we must try to look at it in that
light. And, after all, Cyril has acted on principle. One may disagree
with his principle, but, at least, one can respect it like the French
Revolution, or Cromwell cutting the King s head off. Some of the most
terrible things in history have been done on principle,']
qText:
Nowadays, people don t think so
badly of these things as they used to do, It will be
horribly uncomfortable for them sometimes, but if they are brave,
clever children, as they will be, I dare say it ll make remarkable
people of them in the end. Robert Browning used to say that every great
man has Jewish blood in him, and we must try to look at it in that
light. And, after all, Cyril has acted on principle. One may disagree
with his principle, but, at least, one can respect it like the French
Revolution, or Cromwell cutting the King s head off. Some of the most
terrible things in history have been done on principle,
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I m afraid I take a very different view of principle,']
qText: I m afraid I take a very different view of principle,

qText: Principle! I will go to-morrow and see him,

qText:
But why should you take these disagreeable things upon yourself,

qTextArr: ['It s life that matters, nothing\nbut life the process of discovering the everlasting and perpetual\nprocess, not the discovery itself at all.']

It s life that matters, nothing
but life the process of discovering the everlasting and perpetual

qTextArr: ['Now,', 'I m not going\nto let these silly ideas come into my head....']
qText:
Now, I m not going

qTextArr: ['Don t you think Mr.\nAsquith deserves to be hanged?']
qText:
Don t you think Mr.
Asquith deserves to be hanged?

qTextArr:
['How absurd Mary would think me
if she knew that I almost made up my mind to walk all the way to
Chelsea in order to look at Katharine s windows. She wouldn t
understand it, but I like her very much as she is.', 'Here,', 'is where we differ from women; they have
no sense of romance.']
qText:
How absurd Mary would think me
if she knew that I almost made up my mind to walk all the way to
Chelsea in order to look at Katharine s windows. She wouldn t
understand it, but I like her very much as she is. Here, is where we differ from women; they have

qText: Well, Mary, why don t you say something amusing?

qText: Because I ve got nothing amusing to say, I suppose.

qText: You live with your inferiors,

qTextArr:
['And you get into a groove because, on the whole,
it s rather a pleasant groove. And you tend to forget what you re there
for. You ve the feminine habit of making much of details. You don t see
when things matter and when they don t. And that s what s the ruin of
all these organizations. That s why the Suffragists have never done
anything all these years. What s the point of drawing-room meetings and
bazaars? You want to have ideas, Mary; get hold of something big; never
mind making mistakes, but don t niggle. Why don t you throw it all up
for a year, and travel? see something of the world. Don t be content to
live with half a dozen people in a backwater all your life. But you
won t,']
qText:
And you get into a groove because, on the whole,
it s rather a pleasant groove. And you tend to forget what you re there
for. You ve the feminine habit of making much of details. You don t see
when things matter and when they don t. And that s what s the ruin of
all these organizations. That s why the Suffragists have never done
anything all these years. What s the point of drawing-room meetings and
bazaars? You want to have ideas, Mary; get hold of something big; never
mind making mistakes, but don t niggle. Why don t you throw it all up
for a year, and travel? see something of the world. Don t be content to
live with half a dozen people in a backwater all your life. But you
won t,
