qText:
Oysters, oysters your basket of
oysters!
speaker: William Rodney
refExp: William rose also and stood in front of the fire muttering

qTextArr: ['I had them,', 'in the Strand; I sat on a seat. Well,\nnever mind,', 'I\ndare say some old creature is enjoying them by this time.']
qText:
I had them, in the Strand; I sat on a seat. Well,
never mind, I
dare say some old creature is enjoying them by this time.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I should have thought that you never forgot anything,']
qText: I should have thought that you never forgot anything,
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr: ['That s part of the myth about me, I know,']
qText: That s part of the myth about me, I know,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['And I wonder,', 'what the truth\nabout you is? But I know this sort of thing doesn t interest you,']
qText:
And I wonder, what the truth
about you is? But I know this sort of thing doesn t interest you,
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr: ['No; it doesn t interest me very much,']
qText: No; it doesn t interest me very much,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['What shall we talk about then?']
qText: What shall we talk about then?
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr:
['However we start, we end by talking about the same thing about poetry,
I mean. I wonder if you realize, William, that I ve never read even
Shakespeare? It s rather wonderful how I ve kept it up all these
years.']
qText:
However we start, we end by talking about the same thing about poetry,
I mean. I wonder if you realize, William, that I ve never read even
Shakespeare? It s rather wonderful how I ve kept it up all these
years.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['You ve kept it up for ten years very beautifully, as far as I m\nconcerned,']
qText:
You ve kept it up for ten years very beautifully, as far as I m
concerned,
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr: ['Ten years? So long as that?']
qText: Ten years? So long as that?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['And I don t think it s always bored you,']
qText: And I don t think it s always bored you,
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr: ['You may say you don t read books,', 'but, all the same,\nyou know about them. Besides, who wants you to be learned? Leave that\nto the poor devils who ve got nothing better to do. You you ahem!']
qText:
You may say you don t read books, but, all the same,
you know about them. Besides, who wants you to be learned? Leave that
to the poor devils who ve got nothing better to do. You you ahem!
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr: ['Well, then, why don t you read me something before I go?']
qText: Well, then, why don t you read me something before I go?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Katharine, you ve only just come! Let me see now, what have I got to\nshow you?']
qText:
Katharine, you ve only just come! Let me see now, what have I got to
show you?
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr: ['I believe you only ask me to read out of kindness,', 'Let s find something else to talk about. Who have you been seeing?']
qText: I believe you only ask me to read out of kindness, Let s find something else to talk about. Who have you been seeing?
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr: ['I don t generally ask things out of kindness,', 'however, if you don t want to read, you needn t.']
qText: I don t generally ask things out of kindness, however, if you don t want to read, you needn t.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['One can trust you, certainly, to say unpleasant things,', 'Ahem! The Princess is lost in the wood, and she hears the
sound of a horn. (This would all be very pretty on the stage, but I
can t get the effect here.) Anyhow, Sylvano enters, accompanied by the
rest of the gentlemen of Gratian s court. I begin where he
soliloquizes.']
qText:
One can trust you, certainly, to say unpleasant things, Ahem! The Princess is lost in the wood, and she hears the
sound of a horn. (This would all be very pretty on the stage, but I
can t get the effect here.) Anyhow, Sylvano enters, accompanied by the
rest of the gentlemen of Gratian s court. I begin where he
soliloquizes.
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr: ['That seems to me extremely well written, William; although, of course,\nI don t know enough to criticize in detail.']
qText:
That seems to me extremely well written, William; although, of course,
I don t know enough to criticize in detail.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['But it s the skill that strikes you not the emotion?']
qText: But it s the skill that strikes you not the emotion?
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr: ['In a fragment like that, of course, the skill strikes one most.']
qText: In a fragment like that, of course, the skill strikes one most.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['But perhaps have you time to listen to one more short piece? the scene\nbetween the lovers? There s some real feeling in that, I think. Denham\nagrees that it s the best thing I ve done.']
qText:
But perhaps have you time to listen to one more short piece? the scene
between the lovers? There s some real feeling in that, I think. Denham
agrees that it s the best thing I ve done.
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr: ['You ve read it to Ralph Denham?', 'He s a better judge than I am. What did he say?']
qText: You ve read it to Ralph Denham? He s a better judge than I am. What did he say?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['My dear Katharine,', 'I don t ask you for criticism,
as I should ask a scholar. I dare say there are only five men in
England whose opinion of my work matters a straw to me. But I trust you
where feeling is concerned. I had you in my mind often when I was
writing those scenes. I kept asking myself,  Now is this the sort of
thing Katharine would like?  I always think of you when I m writing,
Katharine, even when it s the sort of thing you wouldn t know about.
And I d rather yes, I really believe I d rather you thought well of my
writing than any one in the world.']
qText:
My dear Katharine, I don t ask you for criticism,
as I should ask a scholar. I dare say there are only five men in
England whose opinion of my work matters a straw to me. But I trust you
where feeling is concerned. I had you in my mind often when I was
writing those scenes. I kept asking myself,  Now is this the sort of
thing Katharine would like?  I always think of you when I m writing,
Katharine, even when it s the sort of thing you wouldn t know about.
And I d rather yes, I really believe I d rather you thought well of my
writing than any one in the world.
speaker: William Rodney
menEnts: [[['Katharine Hilbery']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

qTextArr: ['You think too much of me altogether, William,']
qText: You think too much of me altogether, William,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['No, Katharine, I don t,', 'It does me good to think of you.']
qText: No, Katharine, I don t, It does me good to think of you.
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr: ['William,']
qText: William,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['William,', 'if you still want me to marry you, I will.']
qText: William, if you still want me to marry you, I will.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Is Mr. Hilbery at home, or Mrs. Hilbery?']
qText: Is Mr. Hilbery at home, or Mrs. Hilbery?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['No, sir. But Miss Hilbery is at home,']
qText: No, sir. But Miss Hilbery is at home,
speaker: Parlor-Maid

qTextArr: ['My father is out,', 'But if you can wait, I expect him\nsoon.']
qText:
My father is out, But if you can wait, I expect him
soon.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Is that one of the moderns whom you despise?']
qText: Is that one of the moderns whom you despise?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Yes,', 'I think even you would despise him.']
qText: Yes, I think even you would despise him.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Even I?', 'Why even I?']
qText: Even I? Why even I?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['You said you liked modern things; I said I hated them.']
qText: You said you liked modern things; I said I hated them.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Or did I confess that I hated all books?', 'I forget']
qText: Or did I confess that I hated all books? I forget
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Do you hate all books?']
qText: Do you hate all books?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['It would be absurd to say that I hate all books when I ve only read\nten, perhaps; but   Here she pulled herself up short.']
qText:
It would be absurd to say that I hate all books when I ve only read
ten, perhaps; but   Here she pulled herself up short.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Well?']
qText: Well?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Yes, I do hate books,', 'Why do you want to be for ever\ntalking about your feelings? That s what I can t make out. And poetry s\nall about feelings novels are all about feelings.']
qText:
Yes, I do hate books, Why do you want to be for ever
talking about your feelings? That s what I can t make out. And poetry s
all about feelings novels are all about feelings.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['My mother wants me to tell you,', 'that she hopes you have
begun your poem. She says every one ought to write poetry.... All my
relations write poetry,', 'I can t bear to think of it
sometimes because, of course, it s none of it any good. But then one
needn t read it']
qText:
My mother wants me to tell you, that she hopes you have
begun your poem. She says every one ought to write poetry.... All my
relations write poetry, I can t bear to think of it
sometimes because, of course, it s none of it any good. But then one
needn t read it
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['You don t encourage me to write a poem,']
qText: You don t encourage me to write a poem,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['But you re not a poet, too, are you?']
qText: But you re not a poet, too, are you?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Should I tell you if I were?']
qText: Should I tell you if I were?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Yes. Because I think you speak the truth,']
qText: Yes. Because I think you speak the truth,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Are you a poet?']
qText: Are you a poet?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['No. I haven t written any poetry for years,', 'But all the\nsame, I don t agree with you. I think it s the only thing worth doing.']
qText:
No. I haven t written any poetry for years, But all the
same, I don t agree with you. I think it s the only thing worth doing.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Why do you say that?']
qText: Why do you say that?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qText: Why?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Because,\nI suppose, it keeps an ideal alive which might die otherwise.']
qText:
Because,
I suppose, it keeps an ideal alive which might die otherwise.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['I don t know that there s much sense in having ideals,']
qText: I don t know that there s much sense in having ideals,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['But you have them,', 'Why do we call them\nideals? It s a stupid word. Dreams, I mean']
qText:
But you have them, Why do we call them
ideals? It s a stupid word. Dreams, I mean
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Dreams, I mean,']
qText: Dreams, I mean,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['My aunts!']
qText: My aunts!
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['I come from Woking, Mr. Popham. You may well ask me, why Woking? and
to that I answer, for perhaps the hundredth time, because of the
sunsets. We went there for the sunsets, but that was five-and-twenty
years ago. Where are the sunsets now? Alas! There is no sunset now
nearer than the South Coast.']
qText:
I come from Woking, Mr. Popham. You may well ask me, why Woking? and
to that I answer, for perhaps the hundredth time, because of the
sunsets. We went there for the sunsets, but that was five-and-twenty
years ago. Where are the sunsets now? Alas! There is no sunset now
nearer than the South Coast.
speaker: Aunt Millicent

qTextArr: ['Where are the sunsets now?', 'Do you find sunsets now,\nMr. Popham?']
qText:
Where are the sunsets now? Do you find sunsets now,
Mr. Popham?
speaker: Aunt Millicent

qTextArr: ['I live at Highgate,']
qText: I live at Highgate,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['At Highgate? Yes, Highgate has its charms; your Uncle John lived at\nHighgate,']
qText:
At Highgate? Yes, Highgate has its charms; your Uncle John lived at
Highgate,
speaker: Aunt Millicent

qTextArr:
['I dare say there are very pretty lanes in
Highgate. I can recollect walking with your mother, Katharine, through
lanes blossoming with wild hawthorn. But where is the hawthorn now? You
remember that exquisite description in De Quincey, Mr. Popham? but I
forget, you, in your generation, with all your activity and
enlightenment, at which I can only marvel', 'do not read De Quincey. You have your Belloc,
your Chesterton, your Bernard Shaw why should you read De Quincey?']
qText:
I dare say there are very pretty lanes in
Highgate. I can recollect walking with your mother, Katharine, through
lanes blossoming with wild hawthorn. But where is the hawthorn now? You
remember that exquisite description in De Quincey, Mr. Popham? but I
forget, you, in your generation, with all your activity and
enlightenment, at which I can only marvel do not read De Quincey. You have your Belloc,
your Chesterton, your Bernard Shaw why should you read De Quincey?
speaker: Aunt Millicent
menEnts: [[['Mrs. Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham']], [['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham']]]

qTextArr: ['But I do read De Quincey,', 'more than Belloc and\nChesterton, anyhow.']
qText:
But I do read De Quincey, more than Belloc and
Chesterton, anyhow.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Indeed!', 'You are, then, a  rara avis  in your generation. I am\ndelighted to meet anyone who reads De Quincey.']
qText:
Indeed! You are, then, a  rara avis  in your generation. I am
delighted to meet anyone who reads De Quincey.
speaker: Aunt Millicent

qTextArr: ['Does your friend\n_write?_']
qText:
Does your friend
_write?_
speaker: Aunt Millicent
refExp: she hollowed her hand into a screen and leaning towards Katharine inquired

qTextArr: ['Mr. Denham,', 'writes for the Review. He is a lawyer.']
qText: Mr. Denham, writes for the Review. He is a lawyer.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['The clean-shaven lips, showing the expression of the mouth! I\nrecognize them at once. I always feel at home with lawyers, Mr.\nDenham']
qText:
The clean-shaven lips, showing the expression of the mouth! I
recognize them at once. I always feel at home with lawyers, Mr.
Denham
speaker: Aunt Millicent

qTextArr: ['They used to come about so much in the old days,']
qText: They used to come about so much in the old days,
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

qTextArr: ['You say you live at Highgate,', 'I wonder whether you\nhappen to know if there is an old house called Tempest Lodge still in\nexistence an old white house in a garden?']
qText:
You say you live at Highgate, I wonder whether you
happen to know if there is an old house called Tempest Lodge still in
existence an old white house in a garden?
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

qTextArr: ['Ah, no; it must have been pulled down by this time, with all the other\nold houses. There were such pretty lanes in those days. That was how\nyour uncle met your Aunt Emily, you know,', 'They walked home through the lanes.']
qText:
Ah, no; it must have been pulled down by this time, with all the other
old houses. There were such pretty lanes in those days. That was how
your uncle met your Aunt Emily, you know, They walked home through the lanes.
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

qTextArr: ['A sprig of May in her bonnet,']
qText: A sprig of May in her bonnet,
speaker: Aunt Millicent

qTextArr: ['And next Sunday he had violets in his buttonhole. And that was how we\nguessed.']
qText:
And next Sunday he had violets in his buttonhole. And that was how we
guessed.
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

qTextArr: ['Uncle John yes,  poor John,  you always called him. Why was that?']
qText: Uncle John yes,  poor John,  you always called him. Why was that?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['That was what his father, old Sir Richard, always called him. Poor\nJohn, or the fool of the family,']
qText:
That was what his father, old Sir Richard, always called him. Poor
John, or the fool of the family,
speaker: Mrs. Milvain
refExp: Mrs Milvain hastened to inform them

qTextArr:
['The other boys were so brilliant, and he could never pass his
examinations, so they sent him to India a long voyage in those days,
poor fellow. You had your own room, you know, and you did it up. But he
will get his knighthood and a pension, I believe,', 'only it is not England.']
qText:
The other boys were so brilliant, and he could never pass his
examinations, so they sent him to India a long voyage in those days,
poor fellow. You had your own room, you know, and you did it up. But he
will get his knighthood and a pension, I believe, only it is not England.
speaker: Mrs. Milvain
menEnts: [[['Uncle John'], ['Uncle John'], ['Uncle John'], ['Aunt Millicent'], ['Aunt Millicent'], ['Aunt Millicent'], ['Aunt Millicent'], ['Uncle John'], ['Uncle John']], []]

qTextArr:
['No,', 'it is not England. In those days we
thought an Indian Judgeship about equal to a county-court judgeship at
home. His Honor a pretty title, but still, not at the top of the tree.
However,', 'if you have a wife and seven children, and
people nowadays very quickly forget your father s name well, you have
to take what you can get,']
qText:
No, it is not England. In those days we
thought an Indian Judgeship about equal to a county-court judgeship at
home. His Honor a pretty title, but still, not at the top of the tree.
However, if you have a wife and seven children, and
people nowadays very quickly forget your father s name well, you have
to take what you can get,
speaker: Aunt Millicent

qTextArr:
['And I fancy,', 'that John would have done more if it hadn t been for
his wife, your Aunt Emily. She was a very good woman, devoted to him,
of course, but she was not ambitious for him, and if a wife isn t
ambitious for her husband, especially in a profession like the law,
clients soon get to know of it. In our young days, Mr. Denham, we used
to say that we knew which of our friends would become judges, by
looking at the girls they married. And so it was, and so, I fancy, it
always will be. I don t think,', 'that any man is really happy unless he succeeds in his
profession.']
qText:
And I fancy, that John would have done more if it hadn t been for
his wife, your Aunt Emily. She was a very good woman, devoted to him,
of course, but she was not ambitious for him, and if a wife isn t
ambitious for her husband, especially in a profession like the law,
clients soon get to know of it. In our young days, Mr. Denham, we used
to say that we knew which of our friends would become judges, by
looking at the girls they married. And so it was, and so, I fancy, it
always will be. I don t think, that any man is really happy unless he succeeds in his
profession.
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

qTextArr:
['No, men are not the same as women. I fancy Alfred Tennyson spoke the
truth about that as about many other things. How I wish he d lived to
write  The Prince  a sequel to  The Princess ! I confess I m almost
tired of Princesses. We want some one to show us what a good man can
be. We have Laura and Beatrice, Antigone and Cordelia, but we have no
heroic man. How do you, as a poet, account for that, Mr. Denham?']
qText:
No, men are not the same as women. I fancy Alfred Tennyson spoke the
truth about that as about many other things. How I wish he d lived to
write  The Prince  a sequel to  The Princess ! I confess I m almost
tired of Princesses. We want some one to show us what a good man can
be. We have Laura and Beatrice, Antigone and Cordelia, but we have no
heroic man. How do you, as a poet, account for that, Mr. Denham?
speaker: Aunt Millicent
refExp: Mrs Cosham approved of this sentiment with more ponderous sagacity from her side of the teatable in the first place by swaying her head and in the second by remarking

qTextArr: ['I m not a poet,', 'I m only a solicitor.']
qText: I m not a poet, I m only a solicitor.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['But you write, too?']
qText: But you write, too?
speaker: Aunt Millicent

qTextArr: ['In my spare time,']
qText: In my spare time,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['In your spare time!', 'That is a proof of devotion,\nindeed.']
qText:
In your spare time! That is a proof of devotion,
indeed.
speaker: Aunt Millicent

qTextArr:
['Um um Pendennis Warrington I could never forgive Laura,', 'for not marrying George, in spite of
everything. George Eliot did the very same thing; and Lewes was a
little frog-faced man, with the manner of a dancing master. But
Warrington, now, had everything in his favor; intellect, passion,
romance, distinction, and the connection was a mere piece of
undergraduate folly. Arthur, I confess, has always seemed to me a bit
of a fop; I can t imagine how Laura married him. But you say you re a
solicitor, Mr. Denham. Now there are one or two things I should like to
ask you about Shakespeare', 'They say,
nowadays, that Shakespeare was a lawyer. They say, that accounts for
his knowledge of human nature. There s a fine example for you, Mr.
Denham. Study your clients, young man, and the world will be the richer
one of these days, I have no doubt. Tell me, how do we come out of it,
now; better or worse than you expected?']
qText:
Um um Pendennis Warrington I could never forgive Laura, for not marrying George, in spite of
everything. George Eliot did the very same thing; and Lewes was a
little frog-faced man, with the manner of a dancing master. But
Warrington, now, had everything in his favor; intellect, passion,
romance, distinction, and the connection was a mere piece of
undergraduate folly. Arthur, I confess, has always seemed to me a bit
of a fop; I can t imagine how Laura married him. But you say you re a
solicitor, Mr. Denham. Now there are one or two things I should like to
ask you about Shakespeare They say,
nowadays, that Shakespeare was a lawyer. They say, that accounts for
his knowledge of human nature. There s a fine example for you, Mr.
Denham. Study your clients, young man, and the world will be the richer
one of these days, I have no doubt. Tell me, how do we come out of it,
now; better or worse than you expected?
speaker: Aunt Millicent
menEnts: [[], [['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham']], [['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham'], ['Ralph Denham']]]

qTextArr: ['Worse, Mrs. Cosham, a good deal worse. I m afraid the ordinary man is\na bit of a rascal']
qText:
Worse, Mrs. Cosham, a good deal worse. I m afraid the ordinary man is
a bit of a rascal
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['And the ordinary woman?']
qText: And the ordinary woman?
speaker: Aunt Millicent

qTextArr: ['No, I don t like the ordinary woman either']
qText: No, I don t like the ordinary woman either
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Ah, dear me, I ve no doubt that s very true, very true.', 'Swift would have agreed with you, anyhow']
qText: Ah, dear me, I ve no doubt that s very true, very true. Swift would have agreed with you, anyhow
speaker: Aunt Millicent

qTextArr: ['Charles Lavington, you remember, was a solicitor,', 'But you wouldn t remember him, Katharine.']
qText: Charles Lavington, you remember, was a solicitor, But you wouldn t remember him, Katharine.
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

qTextArr: ['Mr. Lavington? Oh, yes, I do,', 'The summer we had a house near Tenby.\nI remember the field and the pond with the tadpoles, and making\nhaystacks with Mr. Lavington.']
qText:
Mr. Lavington? Oh, yes, I do, The summer we had a house near Tenby.
I remember the field and the pond with the tadpoles, and making
haystacks with Mr. Lavington.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['She is right. There _was_ a pond with tadpoles,', 'Millais made studies of it for  Ophelia.  Some say that\nis the best picture he ever painted']
qText:
She is right. There _was_ a pond with tadpoles, Millais made studies of it for  Ophelia.  Some say that
is the best picture he ever painted
speaker: Aunt Millicent

qTextArr: ['And I remember the dog chained up in the yard, and the dead snakes\nhanging in the toolhouse.']
qText:
And I remember the dog chained up in the yard, and the dead snakes
hanging in the toolhouse.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['It was at Tenby that you were chased by the bull,', 'But that you couldn t remember, though it s true you were a
wonderful child. Such eyes she had, Mr. Denham! I used to say to her
father,  She s watching us, and summing us all up in her little mind. 
And they had a nurse in those days,', 'who was a good woman, but engaged to
a sailor. When she ought to have been attending to the baby, her eyes
were on the sea. And Mrs. Hilbery allowed this girl Susan her name
was to have him to stay in the village. They abused her goodness, I m
sorry to say, and while they walked in the lanes, they stood the
perambulator alone in a field where there was a bull. The animal became
enraged by the red blanket in the perambulator, and Heaven knows what
might have happened if a gentleman had not been walking by in the nick
of time, and rescued Katharine in his arms!']
qText:
It was at Tenby that you were chased by the bull, But that you couldn t remember, though it s true you were a
wonderful child. Such eyes she had, Mr. Denham! I used to say to her
father,  She s watching us, and summing us all up in her little mind. 
And they had a nurse in those days, who was a good woman, but engaged to
a sailor. When she ought to have been attending to the baby, her eyes
were on the sea. And Mrs. Hilbery allowed this girl Susan her name
was to have him to stay in the village. They abused her goodness, I m
sorry to say, and while they walked in the lanes, they stood the
perambulator alone in a field where there was a bull. The animal became
enraged by the red blanket in the perambulator, and Heaven knows what
might have happened if a gentleman had not been walking by in the nick
of time, and rescued Katharine in his arms!
speaker: Mrs. Milvain

qText: In what can one trust, then?

qText:

qText: I ve never seen sparrows so tame,

qText:
No, The sparrows in Hyde Park aren t as tame as this. If

qTextArr: ['Done!', 'That s what always happens just as I ve almost got him,', 'Here s your sixpence, Mary. But you ve only got it thanks to that\nbrute of a boy. They oughtn t to be allowed to bowl hoops here']
qText:
Done! That s what always happens just as I ve almost got him, Here s your sixpence, Mary. But you ve only got it thanks to that
brute of a boy. They oughtn t to be allowed to bowl hoops here

qTextArr: ['Oughtn t to be allowed to bowl hoops! My dear Ralph, what nonsense!']
qText: Oughtn t to be allowed to bowl hoops! My dear Ralph, what nonsense!

qTextArr:
['You always say that,', 'and it isn t nonsense. What s
the point of having a garden if one can t watch birds in it? The street
does all right for hoops. And if children can t be trusted in the
streets, their mothers should keep them at home.']
qText:
You always say that, and it isn t nonsense. What s
the point of having a garden if one can t watch birds in it? The street
does all right for hoops. And if children can t be trusted in the
streets, their mothers should keep them at home.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Ah, well,', 'London s a fine place to live in. I believe I\ncould sit and watch people all day long. I like my\nfellow-creatures....']
qText:
Ah, well, London s a fine place to live in. I believe I
could sit and watch people all day long. I like my
fellow-creatures....
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['Yes, I think so, when you come to know them,']
qText: Yes, I think so, when you come to know them,
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['That s just when I don t like them,', 'Still, I don t see\nwhy you shouldn t cherish that illusion, if it pleases you.']
qText:
That s just when I don t like them, Still, I don t see
why you shouldn t cherish that illusion, if it pleases you.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Wake up, Ralph! You re half asleep!', 'What have you been doing with yourself? Moping? Working?\nDespising the world, as usual?']
qText:
Wake up, Ralph! You re half asleep! What have you been doing with yourself? Moping? Working?
Despising the world, as usual?

qTextArr: ['It s a bit of a pose, isn t it?']
qText: It s a bit of a pose, isn t it?
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['Not more than most things,']
qText: Not more than most things,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Well,', 'I ve a great deal to say to you, but I must go\non we have a committee.']
qText:
Well, I ve a great deal to say to you, but I must go
on we have a committee.
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['You don t look happy, Ralph,', 'Is it\nanything, or is it nothing?']
qText:
You don t look happy, Ralph, Is it
anything, or is it nothing?
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['I ve been bothered,', 'Partly by work, and partly by\nfamily troubles. Charles has been behaving like a fool. He wants to go\nout to Canada as a farmer']
qText:
I ve been bothered, Partly by work, and partly by
family troubles. Charles has been behaving like a fool. He wants to go
out to Canada as a farmer
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Well, there s something to be said for that,']
qText: Well, there s something to be said for that,
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['What d you want to sit on a committee for?', 'It s waste of\nyour time, Mary.']
qText:
What d you want to sit on a committee for? It s waste of
your time, Mary.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['I agree with you that a country walk would benefit the world more,', 'Look here,', 'why don t you come to us at\nChristmas? It s almost the best time of year.']
qText:
I agree with you that a country walk would benefit the world more, Look here, why don t you come to us at
Christmas? It s almost the best time of year.
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['Come to you at Disham?']
qText: Come to you at Disham?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Yes. We won t interfere with you. But you can tell me later,']
qText: Yes. We won t interfere with you. But you can tell me later,
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['If I can t face a walk in a field alone with Ralph,', 'I d better buy a cat and live in a lodging at Ealing, like Sally\nSeal and he won t come. Or did he mean that he _would_ come?']
qText:
If I can t face a walk in a field alone with Ralph, I d better buy a cat and live in a lodging at Ealing, like Sally
Seal and he won t come. Or did he mean that he _would_ come?

qTextArr: ['Miss Markham has already arrived,', 'and this is her dog.']
qText: Miss Markham has already arrived, and this is her dog.
speaker: Mrs. Seal

qTextArr: ['A very fine dog, too,']
qText: A very fine dog, too,
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr:
['Yes. A magnificent fellow,', 'A kind of St. Bernard,
she tells me so like Kit to have a St. Bernard. And you guard your
mistress well, don t you, Sailor? You see that wicked men don t break
into her larder when she s out at _her_ work helping poor souls who
have lost their way.... But we re late we must begin!']
qText:
Yes. A magnificent fellow, A kind of St. Bernard,
she tells me so like Kit to have a St. Bernard. And you guard your
mistress well, don t you, Sailor? You see that wicked men don t break
into her larder when she s out at _her_ work helping poor souls who

qText: I fancy, ladies and gentlemen, that we are ready to commence.

qText: My friends think all this kind of thing useless.

qTextArr: ['Oh, they re that sort, are they?']
qText: Oh, they re that sort, are they?
speaker: Miss Markham

qTextArr: ['What do I matter compared with the cause?']
qText: What do I matter compared with the cause?

qTextArr: ['Action! everywhere! at\nonce!']
qText:
Action! everywhere! at
once!

qTextArr: ['If I liked I could make you go in there or stop\nshort; I could make you walk in single file or in double file; I could\ndo what I liked with you.']
qText:
If I liked I could make you go in there or stop
short; I could make you walk in single file or in double file; I could

qText: Oughtn t you to put something round your shoulders, Sally? Well, did you enjoy yourself?
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['Ah, if only one could get every one of those people into\nthis room, and make them understand for five minutes! But they _must_\nsee the truth some day.... If only one could _make_ them see it....']
qText:
Ah, if only one could get every one of those people into
this room, and make them understand for five minutes! But they _must_
see the truth some day.... If only one could _make_ them see it....
speaker: Mrs. Seal
refExp: Mrs Seal drew a deep breath restrained herself and then burst out

qTextArr: ['Let s have our tea,', 'It was a good meeting didn t you think so,\nSally?']
qText:
Let s have our tea, It was a good meeting didn t you think so,
Sally?
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['But we go at such a snail s pace,', 'You can afford to laugh,', 'but I can t. I m fifty-five, and I dare say I shall be in my grave by\nthe time we get it if we ever do.']
qText:
But we go at such a snail s pace, You can afford to laugh, but I can t. I m fifty-five, and I dare say I shall be in my grave by
the time we get it if we ever do.
speaker: Mrs. Seal
menEnts: [[['Mrs. Seal', 'Mr. Clacton', 'Mary Datchet', 'Miss Markham']], [['Mary Datchet']], [['Mary Datchet', 'Miss Markham', 'Mrs. Seal', 'Mr. Clacton'], ['Mary Datchet', 'Miss Markham', 'Mrs. Seal', 'Mr. Clacton']]]

qTextArr: ['Oh, no, you won t be in your grave,']
qText: Oh, no, you won t be in your grave,
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr:
['It ll be such a great day,', 'A great day, not only for us, but for civilization. That s what I
feel, you know, about these meetings. Each one of them is a step
onwards in the great march humanity, you know. We do want the people
after us to have a better time of it and so many don t see it. I wonder
how it is that they don t see it?']
qText:
It ll be such a great day, A great day, not only for us, but for civilization. That s what I
feel, you know, about these meetings. Each one of them is a step
onwards in the great march humanity, you know. We do want the people
after us to have a better time of it and so many don t see it. I wonder
how it is that they don t see it?
speaker: Mrs. Seal

qTextArr: ['You mustn t wear yourself out, Sally, if you want to see the great\nday,']
qText:
You mustn t wear yourself out, Sally, if you want to see the great
day,
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr:
['My dear child, what else is my old body good for?', 'Shouldn t
I be proud to give everything I have to the cause? for I m not an
intelligence like you. There were domestic circumstances I d like to
tell you one of these days so I say foolish things. I lose my head, you
know. You don t. Mr. Clacton doesn t. It s a great mistake, to lose
one s head. But my heart s in the right place. And I m so glad Kit has
a big dog, for I didn t think her looking well.']
qText:
My dear child, what else is my old body good for? Shouldn t
I be proud to give everything I have to the cause? for I m not an
intelligence like you. There were domestic circumstances I d like to
tell you one of these days so I say foolish things. I lose my head, you
know. You don t. Mr. Clacton doesn t. It s a great mistake, to lose
one s head. But my heart s in the right place. And I m so glad Kit has
a big dog, for I didn t think her looking well.
speaker: Mrs. Seal

qTextArr: ['We were passing and saw a light in your window, so we came up,']
qText: We were passing and saw a light in your window, so we came up,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['We have been to see some pictures,']
qText: We have been to see some pictures,
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr:
['Oh, dear,', 'this room reminds me of one of the worst
hours in my existence when I read a paper, and you all sat round and
jeered at me. Katharine was the worst. I could feel her gloating over
every mistake I made. Miss Datchet was kind. Miss Datchet just made it
possible for me to get through, I remember.']
qText:
Oh, dear, this room reminds me of one of the worst
hours in my existence when I read a paper, and you all sat round and
jeered at me. Katharine was the worst. I could feel her gloating over
every mistake I made. Miss Datchet was kind. Miss Datchet just made it
possible for me to get through, I remember.
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr: ['We have been seeing old masters at the Grafton Gallery,']
qText: We have been seeing old masters at the Grafton Gallery,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['Would you believe it, Miss Datchet,', 'Katharine
doesn t like Titian. She doesn t like apricots, she doesn t like
peaches, she doesn t like green peas. She likes the Elgin marbles, and
gray days without any sun. She s a typical example of the cold northern
nature. I come from Devonshire']
qText:
Would you believe it, Miss Datchet, Katharine
doesn t like Titian. She doesn t like apricots, she doesn t like
peaches, she doesn t like green peas. She likes the Elgin marbles, and
gray days without any sun. She s a typical example of the cold northern
nature. I come from Devonshire
speaker: William Rodney
menEnts: [[['Mary Datchet'], ['Mary Datchet']], [['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Katharine Hilbery']]]

qTextArr:
['Perhaps, Mary,', 'you wouldn t mind giving us
some tea? We did try to get some, but the shop was so crowded, and in
the next one there was a band playing; and most of the pictures, at any
rate, were very dull, whatever you may say, William.']
qText:
Perhaps, Mary, you wouldn t mind giving us
some tea? We did try to get some, but the shop was so crowded, and in
the next one there was a band playing; and most of the pictures, at any
rate, were very dull, whatever you may say, William.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['What in the world are they after?']
qText: What in the world are they after?
speaker: Mary Datchet
refExp: she asked of her own reflection

qTextArr: ['William,', 'thinks that perhaps you don t know. We are going\nto be married.']
qText:
William, thinks that perhaps you don t know. We are going
to be married.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Let me see,', 'one puts hot water into the cups first,\ndoesn t one? You have some dodge of your own, haven t you, William,\nabout making tea?']
qText:
Let me see, one puts hot water into the cups first,
doesn t one? You have some dodge of your own, haven t you, William,
about making tea?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Your tea, William,']
qText: Your tea, William,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I wonder how you find the time to know all about pictures as well as\nbooks?']
qText:
I wonder how you find the time to know all about pictures as well as
books?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['How do I find the time?', 'Why, I always travel with a notebook. And I
ask my way to the picture gallery the very first thing in the morning.
And then I meet men, and talk to them. There s a man in my office who
knows all about the Flemish school. I was telling Miss Datchet about
the Flemish school. I picked up a lot of it from him it s a way men
have Gibbons, his name is. You must meet him. We ll ask him to lunch.
And this not caring about art,', 'it s
one of Katharine s poses, Miss Datchet. Did you know she posed? She
pretends that she s never read Shakespeare. And why should she read
Shakespeare, since she IS Shakespeare Rosalind, you know,', 'She knows enough enough for all decent purposes. What do you women
want with learning, when you have so much else everything, I should
say everything. Leave us something, eh, Katharine?']
qText:
How do I find the time? Why, I always travel with a notebook. And I
ask my way to the picture gallery the very first thing in the morning.
And then I meet men, and talk to them. There s a man in my office who
knows all about the Flemish school. I was telling Miss Datchet about
the Flemish school. I picked up a lot of it from him it s a way men
have Gibbons, his name is. You must meet him. We ll ask him to lunch.
And this not caring about art, it s
one of Katharine s poses, Miss Datchet. Did you know she posed? She
pretends that she s never read Shakespeare. And why should she read
Shakespeare, since she IS Shakespeare Rosalind, you know, She knows enough enough for all decent purposes. What do you women
want with learning, when you have so much else everything, I should
say everything. Leave us something, eh, Katharine?
speaker: William Rodney

qTextArr:
['Because you expect every one else to take all the trouble. I ve seen

the next. And once I counted ten minutes and twenty seconds, and then,
if you ll believe me, she only said  Um!']
qText:

qTextArr: ['I ve got to walk over from Disham,']
qText: I ve got to walk over from Disham,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr:
['Well, Ralph,', 'this is better than Lincoln s Inn Fields,
isn t it? Look, there s a bird for you! Oh, you ve brought glasses,
have you? Edward and Christopher mean to make you shoot. Can you shoot?
I shouldn t think so']
qText:
Well, Ralph, this is better than Lincoln s Inn Fields,
isn t it? Look, there s a bird for you! Oh, you ve brought glasses,
have you? Edward and Christopher mean to make you shoot. Can you shoot?
I shouldn t think so

qText:
Look here, you must explain, Who are these young men?
Where am I staying?

qText:
You are staying with us, of course, Of course,

qTextArr: ['If I had, I shouldn t have come,', 'This is the sort of country I thought you d live in, Mary,', 'Real country.\nNo gentlemen s seats.']
qText:
If I had, I shouldn t have come, This is the sort of country I thought you d live in, Mary, Real country.
No gentlemen s seats.

qTextArr: ['Now we have to find our way through a hedge,', 'It s quite right that they should poach,']
qText: Now we have to find our way through a hedge, It s quite right that they should poach,
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr:
['I wonder whether it was Alfred Duggins or Sid
Rankin? How can one expect them not to, when they only make fifteen
shillings a week? Fifteen shillings a week,', 'I
could live on fifteen shillings a week easily.']
qText:
I wonder whether it was Alfred Duggins or Sid
Rankin? How can one expect them not to, when they only make fifteen
shillings a week? Fifteen shillings a week, I
could live on fifteen shillings a week easily.
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['Could you?']
qText: Could you?

qText: I don t believe you could,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Oh yes. They have a cottage thrown in, and a garden where one can grow\nvegetables. It wouldn t be half bad,']
qText:
Oh yes. They have a cottage thrown in, and a garden where one can grow

speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['But you d get tired of it,']
qText: But you d get tired of it,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['I sometimes think it s the only thing one would never get tired of,']
qText: I sometimes think it s the only thing one would never get tired of,
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['But wouldn t it be on the main road, or next door to a woman with six\nsqualling children, who d always be hanging her washing out to dry\nacross your garden?']
qText:
But wouldn t it be on the main road, or next door to a woman with six
squalling children, who d always be hanging her washing out to dry
across your garden?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['The cottage I m thinking of stands by itself in a little orchard.']
qText: The cottage I m thinking of stands by itself in a little orchard.
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['And what about the Suffrage?']
qText: And what about the Suffrage?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Oh, there are other things in the world besides the Suffrage,']
qText: Oh, there are other things in the world besides the Suffrage,

qTextArr: ['D you know the points of the compass?']
qText: D you know the points of the compass?

qText:
Well, of course, What d you take me for? a Cockney like

qTextArr: ['It s my native land, this,', 'I could smell my way about it\nblindfold.', 'That s Christopher, come in already, and gone to feed his chickens,']
qText:
It s my native land, this, I could smell my way about it
blindfold. That s Christopher, come in already, and gone to feed his chickens,

qTextArr:
['You came by the 3.10, Mr. Denham?', 'They treat us very well,
on the whole. Considering the increase of traffic, they treat us very
well indeed. I have the curiosity sometimes to count the trucks on the
goods  trains, and they re well over fifty well over fifty, at this
season of the year.']
qText:
You came by the 3.10, Mr. Denham? They treat us very well,
on the whole. Considering the increase of traffic, they treat us very
well indeed. I have the curiosity sometimes to count the trucks on the
goods  trains, and they re well over fifty well over fifty, at this
season of the year.
speaker: Mr. Datchet

qText: It s not the kitchen really, but we call it so
speaker: Elizabeth
refExp: Elizabeth hastened to explain to her guest

qTextArr: ['It s the nicest room in the house,']
qText: It s the nicest room in the house,
speaker: Edward

qTextArr:
['It s got the old rests by the side of the fireplace, where the men
hung their guns,', 'Show Mr. Denham the steps,
Christopher.... When the Ecclesiastical Commissioners were here two
years ago they said this was the most interesting part of the house.
These narrow bricks prove that it is five hundred years old five
hundred years, I think they may have said six.']
qText:
It s got the old rests by the side of the fireplace, where the men
hung their guns, Show Mr. Denham the steps,
Christopher.... When the Ecclesiastical Commissioners were here two
years ago they said this was the most interesting part of the house.
These narrow bricks prove that it is five hundred years old five
hundred years, I think they may have said six.
speaker: Elizabeth

qTextArr: ['Will you come out shooting with us to-morrow?']
qText: Will you come out shooting with us to-morrow?
speaker: Christopher

qTextArr: ['I won t shoot, but I ll come with you,']
qText: I won t shoot, but I ll come with you,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Don t you care about shooting?']
qText: Don t you care about shooting?
speaker: Edward

qTextArr: ['I ve never shot in my life,']
qText: I ve never shot in my life,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['You wouldn t have much chance in London, I suppose,', 'But won t you find it rather dull just watching us?']
qText: You wouldn t have much chance in London, I suppose, But won t you find it rather dull just watching us?
speaker: Christopher

qTextArr: ['I shall watch birds,']
qText: I shall watch birds,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr:
['I can show you the place for watching birds,', 'if that s
what you like doing. I know a fellow who comes down from London about
this time every year to watch them. It s a great place for the wild
geese and the ducks. I ve heard this man say that it s one of the best
places for birds in the country.']
qText:
I can show you the place for watching birds, if that s
what you like doing. I know a fellow who comes down from London about
this time every year to watch them. It s a great place for the wild
geese and the ducks. I ve heard this man say that it s one of the best
places for birds in the country.
speaker: Edward

qTextArr: ['It s about the best place in England,']
qText: It s about the best place in England,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Piper! oh, damn! I shall have to get up,']
qText: Piper! oh, damn! I shall have to get up,
speaker: Christopher

qTextArr: ['It s not Piper, it s Pitch,']
qText: It s not Piper, it s Pitch,
speaker: Edward

qTextArr: ['All the same, I shall have to get up,']
qText: All the same, I shall have to get up,
speaker: Christopher

qTextArr: ['Do come in and shut the door!']
qText: Do come in and shut the door!
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['We shall have a fine day to-morrow,']
qText: We shall have a fine day to-morrow,
speaker: Christopher

qTextArr: ['I should like Mary to stroke my head like that,']
qText: I should like Mary to stroke my head like that,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr:
['To begin with, I m very fond of William. You can t deny that. I know
him better than any one, almost. But why I m marrying him is, partly, I
admit I m being quite honest with you, and you mustn t tell any
one partly because I want to get married. I want to have a house of my
own. It isn t possible at home. It s all very well for you, Henry; you
can go your own way. I have to be there always. Besides, you know what
our house is. You wouldn t be happy either, if you didn t do something.
It isn t that I haven t the time at home it s the atmosphere.']
qText:
To begin with, I m very fond of William. You can t deny that. I know
him better than any one, almost. But why I m marrying him is, partly, I
admit I m being quite honest with you, and you mustn t tell any
one partly because I want to get married. I want to have a house of my
own. It isn t possible at home. It s all very well for you, Henry; you
can go your own way. I have to be there always. Besides, you know what
our house is. You wouldn t be happy either, if you didn t do something.
It isn t that I haven t the time at home it s the atmosphere.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery
refExp: she did begin a little speech to him

qTextArr: ['I should like,', 'to study mathematics to\nknow about the stars.']
qText:
I should like, to study mathematics to
know about the stars.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr:
['I don t care much whether I ever get to know anything but I want to
work out something in figures something that hasn t got to do with
human beings. I don t want people particularly. In some ways, Henry,
I m a humbug I mean, I m not what you all take me for. I m not
domestic, or very practical or sensible, really. And if I could
calculate things, and use a telescope, and have to work out figures,
and know to a fraction where I was wrong, I should be perfectly happy,
and I believe I should give William all he wants.']
qText:
I don t care much whether I ever get to know anything but I want to
work out something in figures something that hasn t got to do with
human beings. I don t want people particularly. In some ways, Henry,
I m a humbug I mean, I m not what you all take me for. I m not
domestic, or very practical or sensible, really. And if I could
calculate things, and use a telescope, and have to work out figures,
and know to a fraction where I was wrong, I should be perfectly happy,
and I believe I should give William all he wants.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qText: You have fled, too, then?

qTextArr: ['Fled?', 'From whom d you mean? Oh, the family party. Yes, it\nwas hot down there, so I went into the garden.']
qText:
Fled? From whom d you mean? Oh, the family party. Yes, it
was hot down there, so I went into the garden.

qText: And aren t you very cold?

qText: Thank you, Henry, I m not disturbing you?

qTextArr:
['I m not here. I m at Bungay,', 'I m giving a music lesson
to Harold and Julia. That was why I had to leave the table with the
ladies I m spending the night there, and I shan t be back till late on
Christmas Eve.']
qText:
I m not here. I m at Bungay, I m giving a music lesson
to Harold and Julia. That was why I had to leave the table with the

When you consider things like the stars, our affairs don t seem to

qText: Things aren t easy, anyhow,

qText: No. I want to come with you.

qTextArr: ['You ve several big estates round here, Otway,', 'Any good\nhunting? Let me see, what pack would it be? Who s your great man?']
qText:
You ve several big estates round here, Otway, Any good

qTextArr: ['Sir William Budge, the sugar king, has the biggest estate. He bought\nout poor Stanham, who went bankrupt.']

Sir William Budge, the sugar king, has the biggest estate. He bought

qTextArr: ['Which Stanham would that be? Verney or Alfred?']
qText: Which Stanham would that be? Verney or Alfred?

You have a great reputation as a horseman, anyhow,

qTextArr: ['Oh, I love riding,', 'Could I get a horse down here?\nStupid of me! I forgot to bring any clothes. I can t imagine, though,\nwho told you I was anything of a rider?']
qText:

Stupid of me! I forgot to bring any clothes. I can t imagine, though,

qTextArr:
['I don t care much for shooting,', 'but one has to do
it, unless one wants to be altogether out of things. I dare say there s
some very pretty country round here. I stayed once at Bolham Hall.
Young Cranthorpe was up with you, wasn t he? He married old Lord
Bolham s daughter. Very nice people in their way.']
qText:

it, unless one wants to be altogether out of things. I dare say there s

['I don t find any difficulty,', 'You talk to them about

qText:
I wish you could help her to take an interest in something that other
people are interested in, Katharine, It s all Henry s doing, you know, giving up
her parties and taking to these nasty insects. It doesn t follow that
if a man can do a thing a woman may too.
speaker: Lady Otway
menEnts: [[['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Cassandra Otway'], ['Katharine Hilbery']], [['Henry Otway'], ['Katharine Hilbery'], ['Cassandra Otway']]]

qTextArr: ['It s so very pleasant,', 'to knit while one s talking.\nAnd now, my dear Katharine, tell me about your plans.']
qText:
It s so very pleasant, to knit while one s talking.
And now, my dear Katharine, tell me about your plans.
speaker: Lady Otway

qTextArr: ['What a perfect daughter, or daughter-in-law!']
qText: What a perfect daughter, or daughter-in-law!
speaker: Lady Otway

qTextArr: ['Yes,', 'Katharine is like\nthe girls of my youth. We took the serious things of life seriously.']
qText:
Yes, Katharine is like
the girls of my youth. We took the serious things of life seriously.
speaker: Lady Otway

qTextArr: ['I never _shall_ know my way about this house!', 'I m on\nmy way to the library, and I don t want to interrupt. You and Katharine\nwere having a little chat?']
qText:
I never _shall_ know my way about this house! I m on
my way to the library, and I don t want to interrupt. You and Katharine
were having a little chat?
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I was telling Katharine a few little commonplaces about marriage,', 'Are none of my children looking after you,\nMaggie?']
qText:
I was telling Katharine a few little commonplaces about marriage, Are none of my children looking after you,
Maggie?
speaker: Lady Otway

qTextArr: ['Marriage,', 'I always say marriage is a school. And you don t\nget the prizes unless you go to school. Charlotte has won all the\nprizes,']
qText:
Marriage, I always say marriage is a school. And you don t
get the prizes unless you go to school. Charlotte has won all the
prizes,
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Aunt Charlotte was saying that it s no good being married unless you\nsubmit to your husband,']
qText:
Aunt Charlotte was saying that it s no good being married unless you
submit to your husband,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Well, I really don t advise a woman who wants to have things her own\nway to get married,']
qText:
Well, I really don t advise a woman who wants to have things her own
way to get married,
speaker: Lady Otway

qTextArr: ['What a shame it was!']
qText: What a shame it was!
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['But, Charlotte, it
would have been much worse if Frank had disgraced himself in any way.
And it isn t what our husbands GET, but what they _are_. I used to
dream of white horses and palanquins, too; but still, I like the
ink-pots best. And who knows?', 'your father may be made a baronet to-morrow.']
qText:
But, Charlotte, it
would have been much worse if Frank had disgraced himself in any way.
And it isn t what our husbands GET, but what they _are_. I used to
dream of white horses and palanquins, too; but still, I like the
ink-pots best. And who knows? your father may be made a baronet to-morrow.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['But if you can give way to your husband,', 'a\nhappy marriage is the happiest thing in the world.']
qText:
But if you can give way to your husband, a
happy marriage is the happiest thing in the world.
speaker: Lady Otway

qTextArr: ['Yes,', 'but']
qText: Yes, but
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['We ve all had perfect husbands,']
qText: We ve all had perfect husbands,
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['Not that I think a bad temper is
really a fault in a man. I don t mean a bad temper,', 'I
should say a quick, impatient temper. Most, in fact _all_ great men
have had bad tempers except your grandfather, Katharine,']
qText:
Not that I think a bad temper is
really a fault in a man. I don t mean a bad temper, I
should say a quick, impatient temper. Most, in fact _all_ great men
have had bad tempers except your grandfather, Katharine,
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['But in the ordinary marriage, is it necessary to give way to one s\nhusband?']
qText:
But in the ordinary marriage, is it necessary to give way to one s
husband?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I should say yes, certainly,']
qText: I should say yes, certainly,
speaker: Lady Otway

qTextArr: ['Then one ought to make up one s mind to that before one is married,']
qText: Then one ought to make up one s mind to that before one is married,
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Do look at that lovely little blue bird!']
qText: Do look at that lovely little blue bird!
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['Most women know by instinct whether they can give it or not,', 'And if\nnot well then, my advice would be don t marry.']
qText:
Most women know by instinct whether they can give it or not, And if
not well then, my advice would be don t marry.
speaker: Lady Otway

qTextArr: ['Oh, but marriage is the happiest life for a woman,']
qText: Oh, but marriage is the happiest life for a woman,

qTextArr: ['It s the most _interesting_ life,']
qText: It s the most _interesting_ life,
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['Why don t we all live in the country?', 'I m sure one would think such
beautiful things if one lived in the country. No horrid slum houses to
depress one, no trams or motor-cars; and the people all looking so
plump and cheerful. Isn t there some little cottage near you,
Charlotte, which would do for us, with a spare room, perhaps, in case
we asked a friend down? And we should save so much money that we should
be able to travel']
qText:
Why don t we all live in the country? I m sure one would think such
beautiful things if one lived in the country. No horrid slum houses to
depress one, no trams or motor-cars; and the people all looking so
plump and cheerful. Isn t there some little cottage near you,
Charlotte, which would do for us, with a spare room, perhaps, in case
we asked a friend down? And we should save so much money that we should
be able to travel
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qText: Yes. You would find it very nice for a week or two, no doubt,

qTextArr: ['But what hour would you like the carriage this morning?']
qText: But what hour would you like the carriage this morning?
speaker: Lady Otway

qTextArr:
['Katharine shall decide,', 'And I was just going to tell you,
Katharine, how, when I woke this morning, everything seemed so clear in
my head that if I d had a pencil I believe I could have written quite a
long chapter. When we re out on our drive I shall find us a house. A
few trees round it, and a little garden, a pond with a Chinese duck, a
study for your father, a study for me, and a sitting room for
Katharine, because then she ll be a married lady.']
qText:
Katharine shall decide, And I was just going to tell you,
Katharine, how, when I woke this morning, everything seemed so clear in
my head that if I d had a pencil I believe I could have written quite a
long chapter. When we re out on our drive I shall find us a house. A
few trees round it, and a little garden, a pond with a Chinese duck, a
study for your father, a study for me, and a sitting room for
Katharine, because then she ll be a married lady.

qText: Let me look at your engagement-ring, Aunt Charlotte,

qText:
That poor old ring was a sad disappointment to me when I first had
it, I d set my heart on a diamond ring, but I never

qTextArr: ['Why didn t Andrews tell me himself?']
qText: Why didn t Andrews tell me himself?

qTextArr: ['Do you know, Mary,', 'I ve made up my\nmind.']
qText:
Do you know, Mary, I ve made up my

speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['I ve made up my mind to chuck my work and live down here. I want you\nto tell me about that cottage you spoke of. However, I suppose there ll\nbe no difficulty about getting a cottage, will there?']
qText:
I ve made up my mind to chuck my work and live down here. I want you
to tell me about that cottage you spoke of. However, I suppose there ll
be no difficulty about getting a cottage, will there?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['I can t stand the office any longer,', 'I don t know what\nmy family will say; but I m sure I m right. Don t you think so?']
qText:
I can t stand the office any longer, I don t know what
my family will say; but I m sure I m right. Don t you think so?

qTextArr: ['Live down here by yourself?']
qText: Live down here by yourself?

qTextArr: ['Some old woman would do for me, I suppose,']
qText: Some old woman would do for me, I suppose,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['I m sick of\nthe whole thing,']
qText:
I m sick of
the whole thing,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr:
['I tell you, Mary, it s utter destruction, working away, day after day,
at stuff that doesn t matter a damn to any one. I ve stood eight years
of it, and I m not going to stand it any longer. I suppose this all
seems to you mad, though?']
qText:
I tell you, Mary, it s utter destruction, working away, day after day,
at stuff that doesn t matter a damn to any one. I ve stood eight years
of it, and I m not going to stand it any longer. I suppose this all
seems to you mad, though?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['No. I thought you weren t happy,']
qText: No. I thought you weren t happy,
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['Why did you think that?']
qText: Why did you think that?
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Don t you remember that morning in Lincoln s Inn Fields?']
qText: Don t you remember that morning in Lincoln s Inn Fields?
speaker: Mary Datchet

qText: Yes,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['You re right, Mary,', 'though I\ndon t know how you guessed it.']
qText:
You re right, Mary, though I
don t know how you guessed it.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['I was unhappy very unhappy,']
qText: I was unhappy very unhappy,
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['Unhappiness is a state of mind,', 'by which I mean that it is\nnot necessarily the result of any particular cause.']
qText:
Unhappiness is a state of mind, by which I mean that it is
not necessarily the result of any particular cause.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['I began to find my life unsatisfactory,', 'It seemed\nto me meaningless.']
qText:
I began to find my life unsatisfactory, It seemed
to me meaningless.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr:
['All this money-making and working ten hours a day in an office, what s
it FOR? When one s a boy, you see, one s head is so full of dreams that
it doesn t seem to matter what one does. And if you re ambitious,
you re all right; you ve got a reason for going on. Now my reasons
ceased to satisfy me. Perhaps I never had any. That s very likely now I
come to think of it. (What reason is there for anything, though?)
Still, it s impossible, after a certain age, to take oneself in
satisfactorily. And I know what carried me on']
qText:
All this money-making and working ten hours a day in an office, what s
it FOR? When one s a boy, you see, one s head is so full of dreams that
it doesn t seem to matter what one does. And if you re ambitious,
you re all right; you ve got a reason for going on. Now my reasons
ceased to satisfy me. Perhaps I never had any. That s very likely now I
come to think of it. (What reason is there for anything, though?)
Still, it s impossible, after a certain age, to take oneself in
satisfactorily. And I know what carried me on
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr:
['I wanted to be the savior of my family and all that
kind of thing. I wanted them to get on in the world. That was a lie, of
course a kind of self-glorification, too. Like most people, I suppose,
I ve lived almost entirely among delusions, and now I m at the awkward
stage of finding it out. I want another delusion to go on with. That s
what my unhappiness amounts to, Mary.']
qText:
I wanted to be the savior of my family and all that
kind of thing. I wanted them to get on in the world. That was a lie, of
course a kind of self-glorification, too. Like most people, I suppose,
I ve lived almost entirely among delusions, and now I m at the awkward
stage of finding it out. I want another delusion to go on with. That s
what my unhappiness amounts to, Mary.
speaker: Ralph Denham

qTextArr: ['I don t think it will be difficult to find a cottage,']
qText: I don t think it will be difficult to find a cottage,
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['You ve got a\nlittle money, haven t you? Yes,', 'I don t see why it\nshouldn t be a very good plan.']
qText:
You ve got a
little money, haven t you? Yes, I don t see why it
shouldn t be a very good plan.
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr:
['Yes, Ralph, it s time you made a break. I ve come to the same
conclusion myself. Only it won t be a country cottage in my case; it ll
be America. America!', 'That s the place for me! They ll
teach me something about organizing a movement there, and I ll come
back and show you how to do it.']
qText:
Yes, Ralph, it s time you made a break. I ve come to the same
conclusion myself. Only it won t be a country cottage in my case; it ll
be America. America! That s the place for me! They ll
teach me something about organizing a movement there, and I ll come
back and show you how to do it.
speaker: Mary Datchet

qTextArr: ['Don t go away, Mary!']
qText: Don t go away, Mary!

qTextArr: ['That s what you said before, Ralph,', 'You want to go away yourself and you don t want me to go away.\nThat s not very sensible, is it?']
qText:
That s what you said before, Ralph, You want to go away yourself and you don t want me to go away.

qTextArr:
['I think I ve treated you very badly. That is, I ve told you lies. Did
you guess that I was lying to you? Once in Lincoln s Inn Fields and
again to-day on our walk. I am a liar, Mary. Did you know that? Do you
think you do know me?']
qText:
I think I ve treated you very badly. That is, I ve told you lies. Did
you guess that I was lying to you? Once in Lincoln s Inn Fields and
again to-day on our walk. I am a liar, Mary. Did you know that? Do you

qText:

real ones, and that s what matters. I dare say I m more truthful than

real ones, and that s what matters. I dare say I m more truthful than

qText: Katharine Hilbery? What do you mean?

qText: Katharine Hilbery, But she s gone now.

qTextArr: ['Katharine Hilbery!', 'I ve always known it was Katharine Hilbery!']
qText: Katharine Hilbery! I ve always known it was Katharine Hilbery!

qTextArr:
['I m not mistaken? Surely Mr. Denham? I caught a glimpse of your coat
through the window, and I felt sure that I knew your coat. Have you
seen Katharine or William? I m wandering about Lincoln looking for the
ruins.']
qText:
I m not mistaken? Surely Mr. Denham? I caught a glimpse of your coat
through the window, and I felt sure that I knew your coat. Have you
seen Katharine or William? I m wandering about Lincoln looking for the
ruins.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['First of all, tell me where I am,', 'The ruins my party is
waiting for me at the ruins. The Roman ruins or Greek, Mr. Denham? Your
town has a great many beautiful things in it, but I wish it hadn t so
many ruins. I never saw such delightful little pots of honey in my
life are they made by your own bees? Please give me one of those little
pots, and tell me how I shall find my way to the ruins.']
qText:
First of all, tell me where I am, The ruins my party is
waiting for me at the ruins. The Roman ruins or Greek, Mr. Denham? Your
town has a great many beautiful things in it, but I wish it hadn t so
many ruins. I never saw such delightful little pots of honey in my
life are they made by your own bees? Please give me one of those little
pots, and tell me how I shall find my way to the ruins.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr: ['And now,']
qText: And now,
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qTextArr:
['Now,', 'please tell me what you re
doing here, Mr. Denham for you _are_ Mr. Denham, aren t you?', 'The brilliant young man who writes for the Review, I mean? Only
yesterday my husband was telling me he thought you one of the cleverest
young men he knew. Certainly, you ve been the messenger of Providence
to me, for unless I d seen you I m sure I should never have found the
ruins at all.']
qText:
Now, please tell me what you re
doing here, Mr. Denham for you _are_ Mr. Denham, aren t you? The brilliant young man who writes for the Review, I mean? Only
yesterday my husband was telling me he thought you one of the cleverest
young men he knew. Certainly, you ve been the messenger of Providence
to me, for unless I d seen you I m sure I should never have found the
ruins at all.
speaker: Mrs. Hilbery

qText: Yes, I thought I saw you but it wasn t you,

qTextArr:
['I expect it was me,', 'I was looking for my mother. It
happens every time we come to Lincoln. In fact, there never was a
family so unable to take care of itself as ours is. Not that it very
much matters, because some one always turns up in the nick of time to
help us out of our scrapes. Once I was left in a field with a bull when
I was a baby but where did we leave the carriage? Down that street or
the next? The next, I think.']
qText:
I expect it was me, I was looking for my mother. It
happens every time we come to Lincoln. In fact, there never was a
family so unable to take care of itself as ours is. Not that it very
much matters, because some one always turns up in the nick of time to
help us out of our scrapes. Once I was left in a field with a bull when
I was a baby but where did we leave the carriage? Down that street or
the next? The next, I think.
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qText: But what are you doing here?
speaker: Katharine Hilbery

qTextArr: ['I m buying a cottage. I m going to live here as soon as I can find a\ncottage, and Mary tells me there ll be no difficulty about that.']
qText:
I m buying a cottage. I m going to live here as soon as I can find a
cottage, and Mary tells me there ll be no difficulty about that.

qText:

qTextArr:
['You make yourself think things you don t think,', 'Believe me,
Katharine, before we came here we were perfectly happy. You were full
of plans for our house the chair-covers, don t you remember? like any
other woman who is about to be married. Now, for no reason whatever,
you begin to fret about your feeling and about my feeling, with the
usual result. I assure you, Katharine, I ve been through it all myself.
At one time I was always asking myself absurd questions which came to
nothing either. What you want, if I may say so, is some occupation to
take you out of yourself when this morbid mood comes on. If it hadn t
been for my poetry, I assure you, I should often have been very much in
the same state myself. To let you into a secret,', 'I ve often gone
home from seeing you in such a state of nerves that I had to force
myself to write a page or two before I could get you out of my head.
Ask Denham; he ll tell you how he met me one night; he ll tell you what
a state he found me in.']
qText:
You make yourself think things you don t think, Believe me,
Katharine, before we came here we were perfectly happy. You were full
of plans for our house the chair-covers, don t you remember? like any
other woman who is about to be married. Now, for no reason whatever,
you begin to fret about your feeling and about my feeling, with the
usual result. I assure you, Katharine, I ve been through it all myself.
At one time I was always asking myself absurd questions which came to
nothing either. What you want, if I may say so, is some occupation to
take you out of yourself when this morbid mood comes on. If it hadn t
been for my poetry, I assure you, I should often have been very much in
the same state myself. To let you into a secret, I ve often gone
home from seeing you in such a state of nerves that I had to force
myself to write a page or two before I could get you out of my head.
Ask Denham; he ll tell you how he met me one night; he ll tell you what
a state he found me in.

qTextArr:
['Well, Mary, I m not going to press you,', 'I see you don t
want to marry me. But love don t we all talk a great deal of nonsense
about it? What does one mean? I believe I care for you more genuinely
than nine men out of ten care for the women they re in love with. It s
only a story one makes up in one s mind about another person, and one
knows all the time it isn t true. Of course one knows; why, one s
always taking care not to destroy the illusion. One takes care not to
see them too often, or to be alone with them for too long together.
It s a pleasant illusion, but if you re thinking of the risks of
marriage, it seems to me that the risk of marrying a person you re in
love with is something colossal.']
qText:

want to marry me. But love don t we all talk a great deal of nonsense

knows all the time it isn t true. Of course one knows; why, one s
always taking care not to destroy the illusion. One takes care not to
see them too often, or to be alone with them for too long together.

qTextArr:
['The simple elementary acts of justice,', 'are as far beyond
them as they ever were. We can only look upon ourselves, Mary, as
pioneers in a wilderness. We can only go on patiently putting the truth
before them. It isn t _them_,', 'it s their leaders. It s those gentlemen sitting
in Parliament and drawing four hundred a year of the people s money. If
we had to put our case to the people, we should soon have justice done
to us. I have always believed in the people, and I do so still. But']
qText:
The simple elementary acts of justice, are as far beyond
them as they ever were. We can only look upon ourselves, Mary, as
pioneers in a wilderness. We can only go on patiently putting the truth
before them. It isn t _them_, it s their leaders. It s those gentlemen sitting
in Parliament and drawing four hundred a year of the people s money. If
we had to put our case to the people, we should soon have justice done
to us. I have always believed in the people, and I do so still. But
speaker: Mrs. Seal

qTextArr:
['We must try to consider ourselves rather in the light of a telephone
exchange for the exchange of ideas, Miss Datchet,', 'We should consider ourselves
the center of an enormous system of wires, connecting us up with every
district of the country. We must have our fingers upon the pulse of the
community; we want to know what people all over England are thinking;
we want to put them in the way of thinking rightly.']
qText:
We must try to consider ourselves rather in the light of a telephone
exchange for the exchange of ideas, Miss Datchet, We should consider ourselves
the center of an enormous system of wires, connecting us up with every
district of the country. We must have our fingers upon the pulse of the
community; we want to know what people all over England are thinking;
we want to put them in the way of thinking rightly.

qTextArr:
['To last a lifetime? My dear child, it will last all our lifetimes. As
one falls another steps into the breach. My father, in his generation,
a pioneer I, coming after him, do my little best. What, alas! can one
do more? And now it s you young women we look to you the future looks
to you. Ah, my dear, if I d a thousand lives, I d give them all to our
cause. The cause of women, d you say? I say the cause of humanity. And
there are some', 'who don t see it!
There are some who are satisfied to go on, year after year, refusing to
admit the truth. And we who have the vision the kettle boiling over?
No, no, let me see to it we who know the truth,']
qText:
To last a lifetime? My dear child, it will last all our lifetimes. As
one falls another steps into the breach. My father, in his generation,
a pioneer I, coming after him, do my little best. What, alas! can one
do more? And now it s you young women we look to you the future looks
to you. Ah, my dear, if I d a thousand lives, I d give them all to our
cause. The cause of women, d you say? I say the cause of humanity. And
there are some who don t see it!
There are some who are satisfied to go on, year after year, refusing to
admit the truth. And we who have the vision the kettle boiling over?
No, no, let me see to it we who know the truth,
speaker: Mrs. Seal

qTextArr:
['Reality has to be voiced by reason before it can make
itself felt. The weak point of all these movements, Miss Datchet,', 'is that they are
not based upon sufficiently intellectual grounds. A mistake, in my
opinion. The British public likes a pellet of reason in its jam of
eloquence a pill of reason in its pudding of sentiment,']
qText:
Reality has to be voiced by reason before it can make
itself felt. The weak point of all these movements, Miss Datchet, is that they are
not based upon sufficiently intellectual grounds. A mistake, in my
opinion. The British public likes a pellet of reason in its jam of
eloquence a pill of reason in its pudding of sentiment,
speaker: Mr. Clacton

such thing as affection in itself....']
qText:
It came over me in the Tube the other day, what is it that makes these people go one way rather than the other?

Mary, our affections are the shadow of an idea. Perhaps there isn t any
such thing as affection in itself....

qTextArr:
['If I tell you, then we can talk; and when I m jealous, I can tell you.
And if I m tempted to do something frightfully mean, I can tell you;
you could make me tell you. I find talking so difficult; but loneliness
frightens me. I should shut it up in my mind. Yes, that s what I m
afraid of. Going about with something in my mind all my life that never
changes. I find it so difficult to change. When I think a thing s wrong
I never stop thinking it wrong, and Ralph was quite right, I see, when
he said that there s no such thing as right and wrong; no such thing, I
mean, as judging people']
qText:
If I tell you, then we can talk; and when I m jealous, I can tell you.
And if I m tempted to do something frightfully mean, I can tell you;
you could make me tell you. I find talking so difficult; but loneliness
frightens me. I should shut it up in my mind. Yes, that s what I m
afraid of. Going about with something in my mind all my life that never
changes. I find it so difficult to change. When I think a thing s wrong
I never stop thinking it wrong, and Ralph was quite right, I see, when
he said that there s no such thing as right and wrong; no such thing, I
mean, as judging people
speaker: Mary Datchet
